editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE Muse of New-Market: OR, Mirth and Drollery BEING Three FARCES Acted before the KING and Court AT NEW-MARKET;

row.cell: The Merry Milkmaid of Islington, or the Rambling Gallants defeated.
Love lost in the Dark, or the Drunken Couple.
The Politick Whore or the Conceited Cuckhold.

l.hi: Ut Pictura Poesis erit, quae si proprius stes,
Te capiet magis, & quaedam si longius obstes
Haec amat, obscurum, volet hac suh luce, videri;
Haec placuit sem • l, haec decies repetita placebit.

div.p: Printed for Dan. Browne at the Black Swan and Bible without Temple-Bar, Dan. Major at the Hand and Scepter over against S. Dunstan's Church in Fleetstreet, and James Vade at the Cock and Sugar Loaf near S. Dunstan's Church in Fleetstreet. 1680.
THE Merry Milkmaid OF ISLINGTON; OR, THE Rambling Gallants DEFEATED.

Printed for Dan. Browne at the Black Swan and Bible without Temple-Bar, Dan. Major at the Hand and Scepter over against S. Dunstan's Church in Fleetstreet, and James Vade at the Cock and Sugar Loaf near S. Dunstan's Church in Fleetstreet. 1680.

list.head: The ACTORS NAMES.
list.item: SIR Jeffery Jolt, a half-witted Knight.
Anthony, a Clown, Sir Jeffery's Man.

list.head: VVOMEN.
list.item: Margery, the Milkmaid to Lady Jolt, her Cosin disguiz'd.

div.stage: Enter Sir Jeffery Jolt, Anthony his Man.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: YOu that call your sins your duty, obey your Ladies Riots, preserve her spittle to cure your salt Itch, and thred in Bracelets the Pearls that drop from her Authentick Nose.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Cuds heart Sir, what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: To cleave you from the Scull to the Twist, make nine Skittles of thy bones, and wind thy Heart-strings about my Thumb.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Sir, have a care what you do; so rotten are my limbs, that if you blow on me too hard, I am straight scatter'd into sand.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Coward, creep into my Hour-glass then, and there eternally distinguish fatal time.

sp.speaker: Artez.
sp.p: What Slave disturbs my quiet?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ne're look Sir, I serve my Lady, and scorn to yield.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Dost bristle Pork pine?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Take heed Sir, I have the Malady of France.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Withdraw your violence; if you disorder but a hair that belongs to my meanest Groom, I will proclaim my superiority and rule i'th' streets.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Hell cannot miss thee long.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Insult in thy own Pigs sty, this Apartment calls me Soveraign: Tony, send in one that waits there.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: What will she do at last?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: A slow device Sir, but of my own brain.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: A kind Guest invited here.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: To what?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: To taste your Wives Gammons.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Bold Sir, be in your speech more plain.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I come to get Children for you.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Do you want plainer Paraphrase; he is my servant Sir, my Stallion if I please, a Courtly complement, and much in use among Ladies of my growth and blood.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: O my cold blood, this Woman will distract me.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: You see I'm furnish'd, now your Concubine may share you and the house in peace.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: I step my ears to thy bold clamours: But for you Sir, the minutes you must waste on Earth are few.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: This I consider Sir, and therefore make such hast to mingle with your Wife, that the kind World may have some Issue from my Loyns.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: If this prove true, may Cats piss out my eyes. [Love. draws.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Hold weak Jeff. or else I'le wound thy heart. [Art. draws a Dagger.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: If you advance one inch beyond that Chink, Ple through the streets blow your Dirge, with the great Horn that grows upon your Brow.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: A whole shower of Gall is fallen at once.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: 'Uds life Sir, I come to ease the labour of your body, and you want courtesie to return thanks.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Hang him ingrateful.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: But what hereafter I perform, shall be for your Ladies sake, not yours.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: For all this, I know you will not wrong my Bed.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Who told you so?

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: I read it in your Noble Feature, and your shape.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: The better shapt I am Sir, the more cause you'l have to love the Issue I shall get upon your Wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: I know thou scorns to do't.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Not I, believ't Sir, I must do't; is your Lady fruitful, I would be loth to loose my labour on her.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Death and the Devil. [Offers to draw, they laugh at him,

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: I'le have a Trumpet and a Drum, and sound to the world thy living shame.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: O fie Sir! what own your disgrace aloud, as if you were proud on't.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Nay it becomes you finely.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: You think because you'r eurst we'll allow you short Horns; no, I'le grast upon your head a pair so tall, they shall go near to prick the very Planet that rul'd at your Nativity.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: He sleeps.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Take down a Cushion and pray Sir, you cannot chuse but know the frailty of the times, the surfeits of the Womb, and how great Ladies use to relieve their appetites; your own confession of my parts commends your Wife in her choice; there be them that fin with feeble Ushers, and wither'd Dwarss.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: He wants judgment to consider this.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I merit better looks Sir, that must thrash all night for you, and without wages too Sir.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Dead as a Monument let us leave him.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Hadhe chose the Devil for h • s Physiclan, he could ne're come by the like Cordial, [Exeunt ambo.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: I follow you. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: The day begins to break; and trembling light, as if affrighted with the nights disaster, steals through the farthest ayr, and by degrees salutes my weary longings: new fears assault me; 'tis a Womans voice, and chearfully expresses her freedome: Be propitious thou Regent of my Fate, and guide her hither to my comfort. Singing within.

div.stage: Enter Margery singing, as going a Milking.

l.hi: What a pleasant life the Milkmaids lead,
She trips and dances o're the Mead;
She dabbles in Dew, and sings to her Cow,
And cryes fond love, I defie thee now;
She sleeps in the night, though she toyls in the day,
And merrily passeth her time away.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Ha! what silken Butterflies yonder; she looks not like one that had kept her self warm at the Brick-kills; yet silk Petticoats many times are glad of worse lodging.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Goodmorrow Maid.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Should I salute you so, 't would bring my wit in question: pray what are you?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: A distressed Maid.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: A Maid at your years, and so near London! where the sale of a Maidenhead at fifteen is as rare as a light Wenches Conversion.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Good Maid, Wise, or Widdow, for sure you are a woman, do me a courteous office, and guide me to some house.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: It seems you are a kind Country Gentlewoman, that has bestow'd your Maidenhead on your Fathers man, and are come up to have a Citizen salder your broken ware; the policy is grown stale, 't would hardly take, ever since the Ballet curst the Carrier that brought her to Town.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Do you from the abundance of your own ills suspect mine?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: The Toy is angry, it would fain counterfeit something to make me her Agent but you are deceived my pretty morsel of wantonness, my self and my Pale are both honest; I am not the Blades Intelligencer, whether Doll and M • ll remove their lodgings to escape the Constable, and Bridewell: I will to my Cows, and leave you to the fate of the morning; dispair not of a Customer, but be sure I catch you not napping, for if I do, expect no mercy, for I hate Hedge-coupling worse than sasting at Christmas.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: If you are good, stay and comfort me, the sense of my distress stops further speech. [Sounds.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Ha! she sounds poor Gentlewoman; should she miscarry, I were in danger of being thought her Murdercss; alas she's dead: why Tony, Tony, help me, a Gentlewoman is fallen dead.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why, what is she dead?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Nay, that's as hard to tell as the success of my danger.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Is she quite dead?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I, I, quite dead.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And are not you in a pickle Margery? she is not dead, she moves.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Pull her by the Nose.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I, I, pull it off; no matter for spoiling her face, if she be dead.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Wring her by the little finger.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Her little finger is ring'd, and l'de wring it off if I could.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: No robbing of the dead Tony.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why, what a Devil should the Dead do with living moveables?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Cast water in her face.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Blow wind in her Arse; can water make one alive that's dead, unless it be hot water?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: She surs, give her more ayr.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: E're you return me to my angry Unkle, my soul shall fly, and meet with my dearest imbraces.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why, what a Devil do you mean, Mistress Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: You are murtherers of all my content, you serve the world for base reward, and that shall render you base to opinion.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Prethee Margery let me conjure down this Devil in her tongue, 't will raise a Tempest else, murdere • s and base? pray Gentlewoman, who do you speak all this to?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: To you, the injurers of my love.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Hey day! she's mad; love with a vengeance; come, come, I must take her aside, and give her satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I pity your feeling sorrows, would I could comfort you.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Since my distress has made me an object of your pity, pray lead me to some house, for I am wondrous saint.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: That I will, what e're comes on't, [Exit Marg. Isa.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But pray Margery forget not my Breaksast; rising early, and rambling about, has got me a good stomach; yet I could be content to fast with such laced Mutton, and a good Callice, more than half a morning.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: The blind that Lovechange and I cast upon our actions, must be withdrawn with discretion, lest my Reputation fall in the Encounter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Here's my Lady; now for a trick to put upon her to revenge my Masters wrongs: Madam, as I was in the Market to fetch sweet Bryar, I met a Maid; she told me she was in danger of losing a piece of ground which was her own by Inheritance, and left her by her Mother, now there's a Knight would fain inclose it, and lay it to part of his Mannour.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Where lies this Land?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Not far off; she would be content to let him enjoy it after her decease, if that would serve his turn.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Has she given you any writing to make me better understand the matter?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: This is the Survey, not only of the Mannour it self, but the Meadow, Pasture, P • ow land, Coney-borrow, Fish-pond, Hedge, Ditch and Bush that 〈…〉 ds in't,

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: My Husbands hand to't, and a Love-letter; where had it you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: From the aforesaid party, that would fain keep the foresaid Land from the foresaid Knights fingers.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Sir Jeffery turn'd Ranger?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Madam, you are a good Hunteress; though she love now and then to have a private Borrow ferrited for her own pleasure, yet she won't allow him to run down a Deer: Sir Jeffery would fain be a Ranger, hut she requests you to let him run a Course in your own Park; if you'l not do it for love, then do't for money; she has no Silver, but there's Gold; or else she prays you to Ring him by this Token, and so you shall be sure his Nose will not be routing in other folks Pastures.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: This Purse and Ring was mine, I know them; to requite your pains, take thou the Gold.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No not I, so I may be call'd in question if I came honestly by it.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: These lines are even, the Arrows love let fly,
The very Ink dropt out of Venus Eye:
To me he ne're thus writ;
But Lust can set a double edge on Wit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nay, that's true Madam, a Wench can whet anything, if it be not too dull.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: What is the Creature?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: One of those Creatures that are contrary to Man, a Woman.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: What manner of Woman?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: A tiny Woman, lower than your Ladyship by the head and shoulders, but as mad a Wench as ever untyed a Petticoat.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why should she send back these, and by you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ware, ware, there's knavery i'th' wind.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Did not he send them by you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Never, never, I hope you won't put that upon me.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Are you só close you Baud, you Pandering Slave?

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Why how now Wife, what's your quarrel?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Out of my sight base Varlet, get thee gone.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Away you Rogue; what grown a fighter; prethee what's the matter, how you change, surely you are not well. [Exit Authony.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: All is not well indeed. [She-kneels.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Why dost kneel?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Earth is sins Cushion, Sir Jeffery, Husband I dare not call thee; I have stoln that Jewel of my chast Honour, which was only thine, and given it to a slave.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: On thy Pillow Adultery and Lust have slept, thy Groom has climb'd the unlawful Tree, and pluckt the sweets, a Villain has, usurp'd the Husbands Sheets.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Did I out of a sound faith in you forget the Go • tish Monster you entertained, thinking not to fret my soul by your seeming ludeness, and now to act the sault indeed; 'uds death, who wast made me a Cuckold, who wast?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Your man Tony.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Worse than damnation, bold Strumpet, hang not on me, think'st I'le be a Baud to a Whore, and my Wife too?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: All I beg is, use me how you will, but darken the Clouds of my shame.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: How, conceal my Horns, they cannot be hid, nor shall my revenge; could not I feed your appetite?
sp.l: O women, you were created Angels pure and fair,
But since the Fall you tempting Devils are:
You should be mans bliss, but you prove our Rods,
Was there no women, men might live like Gods:
Get from my sight henceforth, and from my Bed,
I'le with no Strumpets breath be poysoned.
sp.p: But how drew you him in, or could he bewitch you, how was the manner?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Why thus: First he assaulted me with this Battery of beaten Gold, yet I held out; but at last, when this was shot, it charm'd me: what, do you change? who sent this Diamond to your Wench? could not I feed your appetite?
sp.l: O men, you were created Angels pure and fair,
But since the Fall you worse than Devils are:
You should our Shields be, but you prove our Rods,
Were there no men women might live like Gods.
sp.p: Guilty Sir Jeffery?

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Yes guilty, my Lady.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Nay, you may laugh but henceforth shun my Bed,
With no Whores leavings I'le be poysoned. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: O'rereach'd so finely; 'tis the very Diamond and Letter which I sent; this Villain has discover'd all: well, this is the second trick she has put upon me; she varies more in mind than e're the wind had points, still I the fool must be; but if I break her, who is she or me. [Exeunt.

div.head: ACT II.
div.stage: Enter Isabella in Margeries Cloaths, and Margery in bers.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I Hope you are satisfied; but to what end this change is, I would fain be instructed.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I'le tell you, when I left my Unkles house, in a few minutes I was pursued; now this disguize shall help me scape the search.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Now out upon't, had I no better opinion of your honesty than of your wit, both which smell altogether of the Country, I'de leave you to seek your own Adventures: you have gentilifi'd me with your Cloaths, and you are handsome enough in mine; for though I am but a Milk-wench, I ever lov'd neatness: now you shall be my Maid, and wait on me to the City, if I find not out your Sweet heart, let me ne're be accounted a Prophetess; and I'm sure I have foretold weather from the turning up of my Cows Tail.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Dispose of me as you will now, love has arm'd me with resolution.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: In this disguize I'le meet the Blade that Courts me every morning when I go a Milking to Islington, my condition is too low to win upon his desires to marry me, and the other thing without it he shall never have, for I conceive it will not be for my honour. [Tony within.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why Margery, Margery, I say, my Breakfast; a quick supply of meat, drink, and sleep, or I ragepresently.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Bless me, what's that!

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Why 'tis Tony, my Masters Rogue, and my Ladies Knave.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: He'll spoil all again.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Where's this clean-wash'd Chitterline, come give me my Breakfast: Hay day! Margery gentlefi'd, and this Mistress that was ready to die for love Margerifi'd! Now I swear hy Hunger, and that's a strong Oath, I think women have more Vagaries, than the Devil would have Clients, if he were a Lawyer, and pleaded without Fees.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Keep counsel Sirrah, you had best; and if my Lady ask for me, say I wont be lost long: so farewel Tony. [Exit Marg. Isab.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You will not be lost long, he's likely to have a sweet match of it that finds you, yet I could be content my seven yearsservice were no worse rewarded, but the Baggage is as coy as an Aldermans eldest Daughter; she has beaten me a hundred time (Coward that I was for suffering it) for attempting to kiss her: if my hand had slipt going over a Stile or so, 'twould not have vext me to have kist her hand so, though thrown in my face; but now I will revenge it upon her Cream Bowls, over whose sweets I will triumph.
New mischief, I am again delaid, if I forbear my Breakfast but two minutes longer, my Guts will shrink to Minikin, which I'le bequeath to the poor Fidlers at Islington for a May·day Legacy.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Mr. Wenchlove, such a kind of woman my Maid met withall, but as how I am ignorant: Sirrah, call Margery forth.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Which, your Margery Gentlewoman, or your Gentlewoman Margery?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Your trifling's unseasonable, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why Madam, Margery is no more plain Margery, but Margery in silks, the Gentlewoman and she are run out of themselves one into another.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: But where are they?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: For ought I know run away one with another.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Do you run after, and call'um back.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible, who knows which way they are gone? besides 'tis a mist would choak a Brewers Horse, I can't see one hand from t'other.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Madam, my sufpition prompts me you are treacherous, and these fair seeming undertakings traps to catch me.

sp.speaker: Art,
sp.p: Nay then what Mr. Lovechange has told me is true: Sirrah, do you try to overtake them, and we'll follow.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Oh killing Command! the best is it break my Heart, no matter then for my Belly; Hunger I defie thee, Revenge I hug thee, I will lead
a Wild-goose Chace till I come to Islington, where I will score two dozen, and reckon with my Hostesses Maid, whose Belly I have fill'd with Mary-bones and Pudden. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Now Madam, why do you look so wistly on me?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: I, I, 'tis so, now the love of mans society defend me from this abuser of Creation; come not near me thou man of Cloats, thou Mauking of Virility, thou half woman, and all beast, or with these Nails I will tear out thy eyes, and all the double things about thee.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Be milder Madam, there's nothing in me appears to my self so full of guilt, that it should deserve a reproach from you a stranger.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: There's nothing in you indeed Sir, your friend has given me your Character; you pretend to hate women, because women have reason to hate you.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: I hate women by my love of pleasure, no delight has any relish on the wanton palat of my desires, unless seasoned with what's derived from them.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Yes Sir, you may take delight in them, but they little in you; come not near me, there's infection in't; my blood desires no freezing, the Summer of my Youth is not yet half spent, or if it were Winter with me, high feeding and ease requires something.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: She takes me for an Eunuch sure, Lovechange has overdone his part; she has foil'd him, and now he hopes my downfal: sweet Madam hear me, I love you, and my desires are throughly fired, and burn my blood, which nothing can squench but your free enjoying.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Say you so, why I am a Woman Sir.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: I think you are, and one made up for pleasure more than the dull converse of what's defective.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: You say true Sir, I hear it with a heavy heart, but I hope Sir you would not have me make my Husband a Cuckold; I'le lead him by the Nose till I put a trick upon him. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Fie, that's a gross construction, only shame and common knowledge does it, not the act of a Wives wantonness.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: I need no instructions for secresie, trust me a handsome Gentlewoman, dare you kiss me Sir?

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Now it may come about a Pledge for what shall follow,

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Pray Sir, is this a fit place to make ones Husband a Cuckold in?

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Oh the fittest place in the world, let not any weak excuse rob my hopes of enjoying you.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Sir, I defie weakness, should some of my servants come.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Ha Wenchlove! all the Race of mankind is false, I'e watch this eager pursuit he has put upon my Lady, and find a way for revenge; I do love, but 'tis honourably: and that's a Crime now a days.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Come, come, we loose the time that might make the pleasure fruitful.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Indeed I durst e'ne venture to make him a Cuckold, if I were sure you would get a Boy.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Oh! that's doubly sweet.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: And shall he be like the Father?

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: As ever Citizens Son was.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: I mean my Husband.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: I am a Courtier.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Kind Sir, you deserve it for your policy; but I am so fraid.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Mischief on these delays. [Sir Jeff. within.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Artezhim, where are you?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: O me! what shall I do? my Honour, my Honour!

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Vexation racks me, prevented at the very point of happiness.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Pray hide your self, Sir Jeffery will bolt out this way I fear.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Pox on't where, where? [Gets into the Tub.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Happy fortune; here's an empty Tub, get in as nimbly Sir, as if you were a leaping your Neighbours Pale to have a run at his Deer.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: O Artezhim l I have got a sound Bottle in my head, it o're-charges me.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: You make no scruple of pressing upon Womens Retirements.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Would he was drunk as the Devil with Wine mixt with Opium, that he might sleep for a fortnight. [Speaks out of the Tub.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Hum, what's that Wife? O my stomack's sick as a Cat after eating Candles ends.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Would there was nine Kitlings in't.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Step into the Yard, let not the servants see your debaucheries.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: O I am taken quick! why not in this Tub?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Fie Beast, defile a necessary implement of Huswifry; you have been drinking of Healths to Cuckolds, your old frolick.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: He might have been one himself had not the Devil brought him home an hour too soon. [Lovechange to them.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: O Madam! where's Sir Jeffery? Fie, fie, what flinch us, and run home.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: O my head, Mr. Lovechange, my head; what shall I do Wife?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: You have received a blow of the forehead, it looks as if 'twere swell'd.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: No Sir, you nor no man else has given him a bloW there yet, I can't tell when it may be done, there's no more than what has been ever since I was his Wife, three years and more, a long time of barrenness.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: O Lord, Madam! why stay you here? we are a coming to wash. [Throws water into the Tub.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Oh! Oh! I am sick, I am sick. [Runs to the Tub, Wench. starts up,

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Hold, hold, 'eds will you drown'd me.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: How now Tom, what makes you here?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Oh mischief on you Sir, you have spoil'd a good Vomit; I'le lay my life he hid himself from my Wife; you told me he was a woman hater: alas poor Gentleman, to see how things will happen.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Hell take your Wife, and you too; accursed woman that in your curse made man so; Pox of your delays, and fearful denials.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: What, scold so quickly after you Cucking?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Good heart, but that he can't endure a woman, he should kiss my Wife for amends.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: I came hither Sir, for something else than to be scolded at.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Come, come, vex him no more, I'le go sleep a little. [Exit Jeff. Art.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: There will be a safe opportunity for me, I love this Cuckold-making.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Though you intended a Reformation for your self, you might for-bear me, this was your plot.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Mine! I never resolved staidness, but I could alter for my pleasure, nor can I hate or envy it in others, I am only sorry Tom that you should drink water after your sweet Meats.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: O Tony, have you made any discovery? [To them Tony.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Have you been in search of the two Wenches I saw cross the Fields towards Islington.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.p: O then you took notice of 'um; she in the Silk-Gown you shall have Mr. Lovechange, and the Milk-wench you shall have Mr. Wenchlove, I have been condogging with her about it.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Thanks honest Tony, there's something for thee. [He takes the Money, his arms cross behind him.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.p: So Sirs, now here, now there, and now here.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: But Tony, what is the Milk-wenches condition?

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.p: Oh womanish, Sir; she'll cry when she's angry, laugh when she's tickled, and be sick when she can't have her will.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: I mean her Calling.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.p: She is call'd Margery.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Her Profession then.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.p: Not very honest, and yet very honest; she cheats all the world that thinks she is wanton; but you will find that neither your Aunts, nor your Cosins, can keep their Legs so close.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: There's more money for thee, I will try that.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.p: You are as bountiful as a new-made Knight that's in hope of preferment.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: But what sayst thou to that I must have; how was she born?

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.p: Why that you had best ask the Midwife.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Is she a Gentlewoman, or not?

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.p: She is, and she is not; she is a Gentlewoman, because she loves pride, which makes Gentlewomen apt to fall, especially waiting Gentlewomen; then she is no Gentlewoman, because, because, because.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Prethee no more.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.p: 'Tis well he interrupted me, for 'egad I had no more Reason than a Horse: But Sir, I will bring her to the bar of your presence, where she may answer for herself, whilst I convert your bounty into wholesome nourishment, from a Bottle of Canary, and have about with my own Turnep. Exit.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: By your leave, fair Maid.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: What would you have Sir?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: A little pleasure Sweet; come, come, what's your price?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: You mistake me, I assure you Sir.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: As if I had not practised Wenching sufficiently to understand a seeming modesty, I'le come to your Lodging when I know where it is: but say your price, a Guiney, or half a Crown.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Have I found you Gallant, 'tis he who I too fondly do affect: but mum, the truth is Sir, I have a Maiden-head yet, though it be agreed for, therefore I am dearer Sir.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Nay Sweetheart, thou shalt serve, thy Mistress is too dear, I am loath to pay too dear for Repentance; 'tis but changing Offices, let her hold the door for thee.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Pray speak, and mean civilly, you'l not be welcome else.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Good Lady light heels, give your servant leave to practise the Trade you have taught her, that such perfection as appears in this woman should be sold to every base desire: come Wench, I like thy brown complexion, thou dost not paint, and art the likelier to be the wholesomer.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Good Gentleman, he's jealous, and would circumvent her.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Here's half a Crown Girl, methinks 'tis a fair rate.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: What's in me to grant you shall command.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: I take your word, the pleasure of your Bed I must have, I will reward it with a new Gown; come dally not with coy denials.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I marry Sir, but not in this place; but if you please. [Whispers.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Now Jealousie instruct me, I fear this woman's nought.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: 'Tis a motion I like, the pains will make the pleasure more sweet in the enjoying.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Mr. Lovechange, I'le in a word inform you. [Whispers.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: How Fate conspires to make me miserable?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I thank thee, and approve of thy advice; what say you Tom to the Fidlers?

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: With all my heart, send in the Minstrils.

div.stage: Enter Anthony, old Hostess, both drunk.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I, I, we will be merry, and in the gallant fashion: Gentlemen, Musick is common, no man shall stop my ears, nor my throat, we must put in amongst you.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: By all means Tony, 'twill compleat the Medly. [Dance.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nay, we know what belongs to that. [Love, kiss the women.
Come away. [They kiss, and reel out. Exeunt.

div.head: ACT III.
div.stage: Sir Jeffery asleep in a Chair. Enter Lovechange, Artezh.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: O The effects of drinking! I could e'ne curse my own kindness, that am ready still to make more of him, than he does of me.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Why don't you then?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: What Sir, I warrant you'd make him a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: 'Tis only giving a friend leave to do you a pleasure in earnest, which you made me make him believe I would do: the truth is, I do now love you heartily, and have dallied my self into a flame.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Nay, Mr. Lovechange, you were ever kind, but are you as well arm'd as you used to go if he should prove subborn: now 'twill work. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: No faith, I must trust to my single valour; come, demur not, let me enjoy those forbidden sweets, be assured my secresie is as firm as Night and Locks.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Secresie, Mr. Lovechange, no, I'le be open to all the world, nor will I distinguish places, dark or light, 'tis all one to me, were it before my Husbands face.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Hear then, he sleeps securely, never dreaming of any Foreheads arming.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Fie Sir, you are such a tempter, pray forbear, many a woman would not hold out so long.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Consent then sweet Lady, and we'll to it straight.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: (Snores) Ware Horns there.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: O mischief! what noise has waked him?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: An infirmity he has got to talk in his sleep: nay, I assure you, he will rise sometimes, and do the office of a waking man in his dream, and not know of it in the morning.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Room for a Head man of the Parish, a Monster of his Wives making.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: O wicked man! he dreams now that I would make him a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Pray Jove it be no counterfeit. [Sir Jeff. pulls Love. by the ears.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: And have I taken you Sir Lancelot? would you be billing with my Guinivere?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Help to pull him off, Madam.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: For this attempt King Arthur does degrade thee, from a Knight of his Round Table, to be a Squire of his VVives Body; so conduct me to my Bed, where I will beget a Race of VVarriours shall Cage the Great Turk again! and restore Constantinople to the Emperour.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: You mistake: Oh! 'uds death, my Perriwig is not a Turbant.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Peace follows Victory, now let me rest.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Pray Sir forgive him, I dare undertake he'll be sorry when he wakes, if any thing I can do can make amends. [Smiles aside,

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Prove his dream true, when the smart's over I shall forget.

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.p: Madam, some Ladies in the house are not well, and desire your assistance.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: VVho wants assistance? who breaks the Kings Peace? fetch me a Constables Staff.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: He'll dream again, had I best stay?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Now Drunkard, are you recover'd yet?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: VVhat. Mr. Lovechange, and my Wife, where's the rest of your Company?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Gone, being weary of such a Sot as you are, to be drunk so early: I had done well to have served you in your own kind; here was Company enough to have brought me home, and some not far off that used me kindly, whilst you snorted to fright the Fleas, and dream perhaps some wickedness of me.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Come, come, I'le buy my pardon with a new Gown, and a journey into the Country for a Month.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: You know I am easie to be wrought upon.

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.p: Will you discharge Mr. Lovechange?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Not so willingly, though I value it not; no revenge of this dreaming Fox: what is the Reckoning?

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.p: Nine and eleven pence.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: How's that? let's have the particulars, Mr. Lovechange shall know how he parts with his money.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Shall he so, kind Sir?

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.p: Why Sir, Cakes two shillings, Ale as much, a quart of mortified Claret eighteen pence, stew'd Pruens a shilling.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: That's too dear.

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.p: Truly they cost a peny a pound of the one-handed Costermonger, out of his Wives Fish Basket; a quart of Cream half a Crown.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: That's excessive.

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.p: Not if you consider how many Carriers Eggs miscarried in the making of it, and the charge of Isinglass, and other ingredients, to make Cream of the sour milk.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: All this does not amount to what you demand.

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.p: I can make more, two three peny Papers of Sugar a shilling, than you had bread Sir.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Yes, and drink too Sir, my head takes notice of that.

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.p: 'Tis granted Sir, a pound of Sausages, and forty other things, make it right, our Bar never errs.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: This can't be, I'le talk with your Mistress my self. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: I, do Sir, know what you do, put it to her Conscience.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Owl, when do you think he'll find that, she's too deep for you or him either; prethee talk sense.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: No matter, he'll pay all; where is he Tapster?

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.p: Gone Sir.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: How, gone! give me my Sword and Belt.

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.p: I must have the Reckoning first.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Must I pay, must I?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: This revenge he took for your beating him in your sleep, I warrant you never dreamt of all this now,

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Has he such tricks? well, 'tis no matter, 'tis but a large Groat for ebng drunk. Here Sirrah. [Exeunt ambo.

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.l: You'r welcome Sir, some profit comes from hence,
I have o're-reckon'd nine and twenty pence.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: My Master must have a fair Course with you; and so he bid me tell you, besides what other kindnesses he will do for you: but stuff your Pannier, he's resolved to do.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Ah Anthony! why should his lustful thoughts be bent at me? some timely Guardian Angel rescue me from his foul intent.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: A Pox of this whining; what an unreasonable thing you are? there's hardly a quarter in the house that you may not rest your limbs in; and because he has a mind to tire himself in one quarter of yours, you count your self ill used.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: When time gives me a more fair way of opening my self to the world, I'le gratifie thee, if you will but contrive or help to avoid this snare design'd for my ruine.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why, is not this pretty? she refuses the thoughts of my Masters singly opening of her; yet in a breath, she says she'll do it to all the world.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I must confess I am a stranger, and have stragled to this house, and have received my Lady Jolts protection, but yet in return of their bounty I would not shipwrack my Fame: where's Margery? I'le straight consult with her about it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I know what she'll say, Pox on him for a Baudy Knight; nay, and very likely call him Cuckold too, for she is pretty well acquainted with the Constitution of my Ladies longings; but since I find thou hast that out-of-fashion quality in thee, Honesty, I'le assist thee, and save thy Mouse-trap from being baited with Sir Jefferies dry Cheese.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: O how shall I give thee thanks fast enough!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: (Aside) Not a word; I am afraid she's fallen in love with me, and will come on with a powder when she falls to: so to secure all, I'le tell my Lady to spoil him, and fill my Belly soundly to fill hers: Mrs. Isabella, I'le not forget you, adieu. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: You are informed how I have design'd the matter; that is, I must be brought to your Lodging in a Basket, as some Moveable Commodity for your special use; my Master is coming this way, therefore about your occasions, I'le be at your Chamber instantly.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Well, pretty Maid, I will not doubt your performing your promise: to say any more, were but to retard my joys; I'le fly to my Lodging, where in the dear expectation of your coming I'le languish, not to be revived but by your sweet sight: so sweet Mistress adieu. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Oh unkind Wench! hast thou forgot thy Isabella, and all thy Vows and desperate Protestations?
sp.l: I must try the event, Dispair may bring
A good success to an indifferent thing.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Since we have agreed no way but that can be safe, therefore in that great Basket within be you packt up, and directed to me, I'le find out an excuse for my not showing you, I need not say any more.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Ha, my Brother with Margery too! what can this whispering mean?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Pox on't, I do love this Wench; but if I can eat a Meal gratis, 'tis better than to have that Bug-bear Marriage for an everlasting standing Dish: I'le try all ways, if this fail, then I'le take her for better or for worse: Well, into the Basket I go, be as speedy as you can. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I'le be there straight.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: O Margery! thy instant help, or I am most miserable.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Hold, I know your grief, Sir Jeffery, is the cause, I heard him a dealing with Anthony about it, but I can blow that off with ease; make him an appointment, the time, place, and dress, and then let me alone to compleat the Comedy.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Thou hast mitigated my passion with thy promis'd assistance; but what said my Brother to thee?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Your Brother, who's your Brother?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Vertuous Maid, I'le relie on thy secresie, Mr. Lovechange is the man, but conceal it till your Plot has had its scope, then I'le discover more.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Ha! you Mistress Isabella Lovechange, and I not peep into you till now; 'tis she: well, since you have told me one thing, then I'le tell you another to requite you, I love Mr. Lovechange your Brother.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Love my Brother, O beware!

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: If my Beauty, which has been flattered for a taking one, can win upon his desires, I'le soon work him to what I please; nay, rather than the Project fail, he shall enjoy; but fairly, I have another discovery, but that's for the closing pin.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Well, as to your love of my Brother, I'le joyn with you when things are ripe, I have but one doubt.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: What may be that I am not a Gentlewoman, you shall know that there's many a Gentlewoman has stroakt the Dug: Hark, I hear Wenchlove I must retire, call for the Basket, all shall be well. [Exit,

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I'le force my passion for once, here's the Gentleman: hold Heart, can he be so near, and I not reproach him? [Wench. to them.

div.stage: Enter two men carrying a Basket, Lovechange in't.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Now Wench, is all ready?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I have packt her up like a Dormouse in a Box, I warrant you for hurting her.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: 'Tis a good Wench, I'le give thee a fine Petticoat for this.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I thank you Sir; when you are a weary of my Mistress, and cast her off, as I know you must have change, you shall have my Maidenhead at the same rate; if you please, I'le keep it for you.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Pray use her ne're the worse for my promise.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: The better I'le turn her off within this fortnight, and send for thee.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: O Sir! 'tis not fit a Servant should shift her Mistresses Plate before the Bones are clean pickt; you have Flesh enough to hold out a Month.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: It shall be a Month then.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Pray Sir let me ask you one question.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Quickly then.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: How many Maidenheads have you bought thus?

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Some nineteen with thy Mistress.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Pray let me make up the score an even reckoning.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: It shall, it shall; go away with your burthen-fellows, farewell Wench. [Exit Wenchlove, Basket.

sp.speaker: Marg
sp.p: Now Mistress, what think you of it? have not I taken a course to let the Blades find their errour?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Now I am instructed wholly to commend your Vertue, and steer my course by your example; 'tis time to be gone, Lust is a guilded Pill,
sp.l: It mocks the Sense with pleasure, but at last,
The shining out-side leaves a bitter tast. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: And is she resolved? shall I enter the Port securely?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: The Harbour is deep, yet the water flows but seldome, the passage free from drownding: But should my Lady know this.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Oh, ne're fear that, she has had her fling, and still she bobs me with it, only devises to try me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: She has try'd you too much her own way, I believe therefore I think she need not doubt you now with any other: but the Plot is thus; the Young Sinner that must be, if you can make her so, will come like Mother Red Cap to buy Malt of you; then take her into the Counting House, and try what Figure you can bring her to; a Cypher you need not fear, and the round O is the compleating of your sum.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Anthony, I'le give thee Margery for this exploit, but you must be very careful my Wife take not the sent.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I'le set a naked man in her way Sir, that will imploy her longer than you will be playing the blunt Prize of dried Mary-bones, and young Coney-skins.

div.stage: Enter Wenchlove, two Men, a Basket.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I'le vow 'tis heavy.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: That's strange, and she a light Wench.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You say true Sir, 'tis enough to break ones back.

sp.speaker: VVen.
sp.p: His mistake hits upon truth, rest you a while then, O witty Luxury! how it accutes invention, makes barren faculties beget new issues of rare conceipts: Pox on't, here's Sir Jeffery Jolt, he'll certainly stop me: Oh how I long to see how she looks after this close confinement! she thinks to have me closer anon, and so she shall.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: O Tony! so there's VVenchlove, what must we do with him?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well enough, he's upon the like design, see what's in the Basket.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: O Mr. VVenchlove, what's here? let's see, I can't open it; what's in't? what's in't?

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Would 'twere his Wife, I'd be revenged for this rudeness: let it alone, Sir Jeffery, 'tis only a thing that I have a great mind to experiment.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Look Tony, what shall I do now? [Enter Art. like Mother Red Cap.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: To her, ne're mind him, ne're mind him: now 'ware a Storm.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: 'Tis needless to trifle time, I love, and must enjoy thee.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Oh fie Sir! what will your Lady say to this, if we be catch'd?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Fear not that, good Cuckquean, she'll ne're think of such a thing.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: What, Mother Red Cap? how goes Cakes and Maidenheads? This is not Mother Red Cap: what, my Lady Jolt?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Let him ne're see my face more. O indignity to my Beauty! die you weak Villain: O me! how shall I vent my passion?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I can hold out no longer, let me out. [Lovechange in the Basket.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Whence came this voice? what, have you got an Humble Bee in your Basket, or a Flesh Fly? [Comes out.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: 'Uds death, I have been sufficiently mortifi'd.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: How came all this?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I'le tell you, bargaining for a little pleasure with a young Gentlewoman, whom I thought to be a Wanton, she ingaged me in this Adventure to come to her.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Pox on't, I am baffled in the same Noose, I expected her to be in the Basket: Oh! where is this witty Contriver?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Here Sirs, and am come to laugh at all your follies; for I know Sir Jeffery is in the same Labyrinth: but we must make all well again, for he was set on by Tony, and me; but he and she thought it true, Madam Jolt is privy to all this.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: 'Tis truth, Jeff. this I'le forgive, but no more, if you do, I go to work: Now Girls, if you were well fitted, a Husband is the least you can expect; and now Margery I'le discover, you was my Brothers Daughter, put to me to conceal for a time, the reasons best known to my self.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: To avoid prolixity, see Isabella, who ever had a Chast Flame for this wild Wenchlove, and Margery for you.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Then by joynt consent we'll end the day with mirth: to Pancras, and be marri'd straight; Sister, I am glad I have found you in no worse Company.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Then vertuous Isabella, do you forget what Heats of Youth has made me guilty of, and I'le remember to be ever just to you.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: And thou, Margery, deservest more than I can ever repay or express.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Let me have but all you can do, and I'le never complain.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No, 'tis I must complain, that thought to have had Margery instead of my wages: but for this trick, the next Maid that comes, down she goes, after once she has dropt a Duck to my Lady.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: You see, Gallants, what success attends your Enterprize.
Henceforth account not every lively Wife
Wanton, because she lives a merry life.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: So here's a double comfort, being wedded,
She's neither false, nor am I jealous headed. [Exeunt.

div.head: The PROLOGUE.

l.hi: YOu'r not t' expect from hence the Modish sport,
Abusing either City, or the Court:
The Poet's mannerly, and cautious too
And neither will affront himself, nor you.
'Faith, both are needless, since 'tis done each day,
By you who judge, and him who writes a Play:
Nor does he Controversies set afoot,
But thinks it better if none else wou'd do't;
Nor tells you what Religion he is on;
May be, like some of you, he is of none:
You'r easily pleas'd, and please the Poets too,
Now that the Criticks have no more to do:

div.l: The Devil's in them that censure Farce and Show;

l.hi: Who'd be a Poet then, at least to you?
Who, when he writes, is fool and Coward too.
How do you murther men of that Profession?
There's hardly one that ever scapes a Session:
For once be courteous to a Country Muse

div.l: Untaught, such Tricks the Wits of London use;

l.hi: And in short time, he may find out the way
To write fine Poppet Plays as well as they.
ANd how? and how? Gallants, what is't but so?
Our Female Sex Abhors short things, we know.
But tell me, 'Faith, is it not better far
To ride in Flying Coach, than Dronish Car?
Great Theaters, like Husbands cloy'd, move on,
Without long preparation nothing's done;
We finish thrice, e're they have once begun.
One bout for Broths and Jelly cost you there
More than would buy six merry Pushes here;
Nay, to oblige you, we'll truck Ware for Ware.
Tell me, good Houswifes, is not the pleasure more, when Butter quickly comes,
Than to be three long hours a jogging of your Bums.
To you, Gallants, our sport no trouble brings,
All your delight we know's in little things:
Likewise we so unconscionable are,
We covet to enjoy you only h • re:
Yet for variety, try all the rest,
That will convince you our things are the best.
See us again when you have roam'd your fill,
And, like good Wives, we'll make you welcome still.

div.p: LOVE LOST IN THE DARK; OR, THE Drunken Couple.

LONDON: Printed for Dan. Browne at the Black Swan and Bible without Temple-Bar, Dan. Major at the Hand and Scepter over against S. Dunstan's Church in Fleetstreet, and James Vade at the Cock and Sugar Loaf near S. Dunstan's Church in Fleetstreet. 1680.

list.head: ACTORS NAMES.
list.item: A Dorio, a Libertine beloved by Calista.

list.head: VVOMEN.
list.item: Calista, a vertuous young Lady in love with Adorio.
Mittilla, her Maid, in love with Adorio.

div.head: LOVE lost in the DARK; OR, The DRUNKEN COUPLE.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: MAdam Muggulla, you most joyfully are met to pleasure me.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: It may be so; I us'd to pleasure many: here lies my way; I do beseech you, Sir, keep your own Voyage.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Nay, be not so short, I must with you.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: With me! I pray Sir; what, what Sir, do you see in me?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Do not mistake me, dear Beauty, nothing but honesty i'faith.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Hang honesty, Trump not me up with honesty: do you mark Sir, I have a charge, and a special charge Sir, and 'tis not honesty can win on me Sir.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Prethee conceive me rightly.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: I conceive you.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: But understand.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: I will not understand, I cannot, nor I do not understand.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: But prethee Muggulla, let my young Master Camillo see thy Mistress; but look upon her, and do you stand by.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: How's this? shall I stand by? what do you think of me? Now by the vertue of the place I hold, you are a paltry Squire to tempt my trust thus; I am no Helen to be defloured of my Loyalty, by your fair language.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: You mistake me still.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: It may be my place will bear me out in't, and will mistake you still, make your best on't. Cal. A Pox upon you, let him but have a glance at her.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: The Devil's in you, he shall never see her.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: This is a Croan in grain; thou art so testy, prethee take breath, and know thy friends.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: I will not: I have no friends, nor will I have any this way: but now I call to mind, why will he see her?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Because she loves him woundily, and he loves her totally.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: She hates him damnably, most wickedly, take that upon my word, and swears her eyes are sick when they see him: how fearfully have I heard her rail against him, and cast, and rail again? call for hot waters, and then rail again?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I'le believe a Witch that has been nine years dead, before this.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p:
I have heard her swear, that he is the beastliest man: what a grief must this be? Sir-reverence of the Company, a rank Whoremaster, ten Livery Whores, she assur'd me on her Credit, with weeping eyes she spoke it,
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
and seven Citizens Wives, besides all Volunteers that serve under him, and of all Countries.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: The Devil never father'd such a Lye.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Besides, he is so careless of his body, which is a foul fault in him.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Come, leave fooling, 'tis a meer Fable drawn from thy Ancient Vertues; may be 'tis her Maid is angry with him, because he woo'd her with his Honour; and you mistake.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: She hates him very well too, but her Mistress hates him heartily: Look upon him! on my Conscience she would see the Devil first, with eyes as big as Saucers; when I but nam'd him, she lept back thirty foot.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: That's a lye by five and twenty.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: If once she smell him, (for certainly he is rank, she says extreme rank, and the wind stands with him so) she's gone for ever.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: For all this he shall see her, and give her such a heat, that the Hoegoe of her Constitution shall perfume his Chamber for two long hours after.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Has he any new eyes when those are scratcht out, or a Nose to clap on warm? Is he proof against a Piss-pot? which if they bid me, I must throw upon him.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Well then, a Devil take you, he shall not see her.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: His Dam coddle you for his Supper, if he do.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Then be so far his friend, good parch'd-handed Muggulla, as to give her this Letter, and leave thy pleasant lying, or leave it in her Pocket, there's no harm in it, do't, and I'le take thee up a Petticoat.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Take up my Petticoat, I scorn the motion, I scorn it with my heels, take up my Petticoat.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: And so hot, Reverent Muggull.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Sir, you shall find me hotter, if you take up my Petticoat.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I'le give you a new Petticoat.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: I scorn your gift, give your Masters old Boots, you give a Petticoat: Alas, you'r too young Sir, you are too young to circumcize me that way; take up my Petticoat, I am a woman, a Gentlewoman, a woman of another way; he that takes up my Petticoat, shall have enough to do I warrant him; I would sain see the proudest of you all dare to do it.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Still mistakes: what a Pox do you look at the wrong end of the Prospective Glass.

sp.speaker: Mrg.
sp.p: Petticoat! you shew now what you are; but do your worst Sir.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: A Wild-fire take thee, what ails thee?

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: I ask no favour of you, and so I leave you; and withall, I charge you in my own name; for I would have you know, that in this place I represent my Ladies Person.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: The Devil could not have pickt out such a Representative.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Upon your life do not dare to follow me; for if you do, I know you have a standing that way: but if you do, look to't, look to't. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Go, and the Pox go with thee, if thou hast so much moysture as to receive it; for thou wilt have 'um, though a Horse bestow'um; I must devise a way, for he must see her, and very suddenly; and Madam Petticoat, it all the wit I have, and this can do, I'le make you sell your charge and your place. But here they come.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I know I wrong my modesty.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: And wrong me in being so importunate, for that I neither can nor must grant.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: A hard sentence from him, I have chosen my Judge: Alas Sir, did I approach you with unchast Desires, a sullied Reputation, or were deform'd, as it may be I am, though many affirm I am something more than handsome.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I dare swear it.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Or if I were no Gentlewoman, and breed courtesie, you might with some pretence of reason slight what you should sue for.

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.p: I'm sure I should; the Fleas are cursed troublesome: Hey day! there's a Legion of young Cupids in my Breeches.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Pray Sir, name my defects; when once convinced, I trouble you no further.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: Then I will bluntly and truly tell you, you are too honest (a noted Libertine I profess my self) and talk too soon of Marriage: Can I part with my uncurbed liberty, and on my Neck wear such a heavy Yoak? No, let crooked Hams, declining Shoulders, furrow'd Cheeks, be aw'd by Ceremonies; if you love me in the way young people should, I'le fly to meet you, and we'll meet merrily.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: 'Tis strange such a man can use such language.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: My tongue speaks my heart freely: Fair one, think on't, a close or private Mistress is Court Rhetorick; a Wife is a meer rustick device; and so good morrow.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: How like you this, Caland ino?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: A well-bred Gentleman, I am now thinking whether or no in the dark, or drunk, I formerly might not have met his Mother; he must have some drops of my blood in him, for at his years I was much of his Religion.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: You may perceive I seek not to displant you, where you desire to grow; for further thanks, 'tis needless complement. [Cam. stops him.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Only your patience one moment.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: Sir, be brief then.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: Pray, observe. [Cam. shrugs, makes faces.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: How he looks like a School-boy that has plaid the Truant, and went to be Breeched.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: A new affliction; after all this preparation, I am obliged to hear you,

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Madam—while I at all parts (without boast) his Equal, in vain pursue you, you follow one that with winged feet flies from you, and attempts to undermine the Fortress of your Honour; nay, and more, your Virgin Honour.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: My friend Camillo here's an Ass; what a Devil has he to do with Virgin Honour? when he should speak to the purpose, of the delight to meet in the old Dance between a pair of sheets, my Granam calls it the peopling of the World.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: To vindicate my Honour, is needless; I don't fear the worst aspersion malice can throw upon it.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p:
Can you undergo the scorn of being refused, for which I deeply
suffer? I must confess it makes for my ends; but his ills shan't make way for my good intents.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: You take that Sir, which yet I never granted.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Calandrino, stand to me, I'le force more, Sir; was she, this excellent she, mad to be a slave to your lusts, and used as Physick after drunken Surfeits? mankind must rise against thee, must we not, Callandrino?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I, I, come, come, mankind must rise about it. [Camillo draws. Callandrino.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.p: Murther!

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: Help!

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Nay, nay, stand still, or you'r disabled for ever.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: 'Uds death.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: After a whining Prologue, who would look for such a rough Catastrophe? nay, come Sir, fear nothing; and do you hear Sir, yet I love you too; if you take the Wench now, I'le post it first, then Chronicle you were beaten to't.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: A memorable piece of valour this between you; it may perhaps deserve her Shooe-string for a Favour; wear it without my envy, but expect for this affront, when time serves, I shall call you to a strict account. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Nay, let him go to thy Mistress Boy; if I were in thy shirt, how I could nick it?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Madam, I fear my passion has offended; 'twas my excess of love to do you right.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.p: You have sought my favours Nobly, and I am justly punished in wild Adorio's contempt and scorn: more I cannot say, but that I truly pity you, and wish you a better choice, which in my prayers, Camillo, I ever will remember. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: 'Tis a sweet Rogue, what Thunder-struck!

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I am not so happy: O that I were but Master of my self, you should soon find me nothing.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: What would you do?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: With one stab give a fatal period to my woes and life together.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: For a Woman, better the Kind were lost, and Generation maintained a new way.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Yet all this is nothing to Calista.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Down into the Country amongst your Tenants, there you shall command twenty Calista's, for every night a fresh and lusty one, Nut-brown wholesome Girles, I have bred 'um to it; should their Fathers murmure, straight his Lease is void.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Hang thee, and thy folly, come away. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Censur'd, Madam! what Lord or Lady lives worthy to sit a competent Judge on you?

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.p: Yet black detraction will find faults, when there are none.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Her foul mouth is stopt; you being the Object, rest secure of this, all the Braveries of the City run mad for you: Come, come, 'tis nothing for you, being a simple Maid, that never had a hand in the Honey-pot of Pleasure, to sorbear it: but such as have lickt there, and lickt there often, and felt the sweetness, will.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: How her mouth runs o're with the rank imagination?

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: If such can, as I nam'd before, the Kickshaw being offered, refuse to take it, they may be Sainted, though for my part I don't think it possible to be deni'd.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Not stir abroad, the use and pleasure of my eyes denied me?

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: Insufferable!

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Nor write, nor yet receive an amorous Letter?

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: Not to be endured.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Nor look upon a man?

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Flat tyranny, insupportoble tyranuy to a Lady of young blood.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: She is my Mother that commands it, how shall I decline it?

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: Run away, take any course.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: But without means, how shall we live?

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: What a question's that? as if a Bucksome Lady could want maintenance in any place in the world where there are men, wine, meat or money stirring.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Rather than in a thought or dream, I'le consent to ought that may take from my Honour, I'le endure more than my Mother can impose upon me.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: I grant your Honour is a glorious dressing, but without conversation of men a kind of nothing; she may as well command you when you are a hungry not to eat, or drink, or sleep; and yet all these are easie, compar'd to the not seeing of a man: I will not urge Camillo's love, but make tryal of Adorio.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: And give my Honour to his lust.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: There's no such thing intended, Madam; yet now I think on't, write to'um both, catch one fast, and then throw the other in Mirtilla's mouth.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: 'Tis a business to be considered on.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: When the satisfaction of your love's in question, to talk of consideration is of no moment; if your Mother would allow you a Dancer in the morning to well-breath you, a Songster in the afternoon to open your Pipes, a Servant to air you in the evening, you might bear it; but not to see, or talk, or touch a man, O abominable!

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Do not my blushes speak how willingly I would assent?

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: Do something, Madam, to deserve'um, and blush after.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: I, I, do something as Mirtilla. [Exeunt.

div.head: ACT II.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: SIr, Sir, are you ready?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: To do what? I am sure 'tis not yet Dinner time.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p:
True; but I asher such a dainty bit for Breakfast, as yet I never cook'd; 'tis not Potargo, sri'd Frogs, Potato's marrow'd, Cavier, Carps Tongues, the Pith of an English Chine of Beef, nor the Italian oyled Mushroom, and yet a drawer on too; and if you show not an appetite, and a strong one, I'le not say to eat, but devour it, without Grace too, for it will
not stay a Preface: I am shamed, and all my provocatives will be jeer'd at.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Art thou in thy wits? what new-found Rarity hast thou discover'd?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: No such matter Sir, it grows in our own Country Sir.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Leave prating, and serve it up Sirrah, bring in your dainty.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: 'Twill bring in it self, it has life and spirit in't, and for proof: Behold now, fall to boldly, my life on't it comes to be tasted.

div.stage: Enter Mirtilla with a Letter and a Ring.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Ha! Calista's Maid; you'r welcom fair one, aims your designs at me?

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: I am trusted with a business of consequence, which I would to your private ear deliver.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I told you so, give her Audience on your Couch, 'tis a fit State for such an Ambassadress; dispatch first for your Honour, you know what follows.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Come Sir, will you please to vanish, or I'le—

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: O Sir! pray don't; O Sir! pray don't forget how you us'd your Taylors Daughter when she brought you home a Stomacher to keep your Breast warm. [Exit running.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Now, pretty one, your pleasure, you shall find me ready to serve you; if you'l put me to my Oath, I'le take it upon this Book.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: O Sir, the favour is too great, and far above my poor ambition; I must kiss your hand in sign of humble thankfulness.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: So modest.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: It well becomes us Maids Sir, spare those blessings for my Noble Mistress, this speaks her chast desires with this Ring.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Oh the powerful Charms by that fair hand set down, Heaven be pleased to qualifie this excess of happiness, or I shall expire with a Surfeit of felicity! with what art the cunning Lapidary has here exprest the Rape of Proserpine; I apprehend her purpose, and oblige it, yet not as a helping friend, but a Husband; I will meet her Vertues flame with a lawful heat, and warm our Hymenical Sheets with such delights as leave no Sting behind'um.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: You speak well, and I believe you.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Would you ought else?

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: I would carry some Love-sign to her, and now I think on't, the kind salute you offer'd me at your entrance, hold it not impudence that I desire it, I'le faithfully deliver it.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: A kiss; you must excuse me, I was then my own, now wholly hers; but there's Gold to bind thee still my Advocate, I'le not fail the appointed time. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: Not a kiss; I was coy when it was offered; and now justly, when I begged one, am deni'd.
sp.l: If I catch either still my game's well plaid,
But if I miss I'm with repentance paid. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: You are mistaken, I cannot be the man you are sent to.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Not you the man, you are the man of men, and such another in my Ladies eye never to be discover'd.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: I am a meer stranger to thee,—or will at least seem so. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Still the more probable, since Ladies as you know affect strange dainties: this is not an Age in which Saints live, but women, knowing women.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: As most are at a coupling age.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Why Sir do you Gallants travel, but at their returns to discourse the difference in forreign Females; as the lusty Girl of France, the sober German, the plump Dutch Fr • , the stately Dame of Spain, the Roman and spritely Tuscan, the merry Venetian Curtizan, the English fair Companion, that learns something from every Nation, and will fly at all.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: But may I ask without offence your gravity, what Title your Lady bears in this City?

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: If you were true Town-bred, you would do the business first, and ask that after: Sir, she's no Half-crown Trader, nor no Beldam so frozen up, a Feaver can't thaw her.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: Leave this impertinence, and come to the matter.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Impertinence! what my Granams Cat left in the Mault in Impertinence teeth; if it be impertinent to say her Name's Calista, God buy to you, and your impertinence too.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: Oh I have heard of her, for Chastity and Beauty the wonder of the age!

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Pray not too much of that Sir, fair and free, I'le subscribe too, and you'l find her so.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: This can't be Calista, your covering your foul ends with a fair name, gives me just reason to suspect you have a plot upon my life.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: A Plot! very fine; nay 'tis a dangerous one, beware on't: I plot to bring you in a minutes space to those a man of Snow would ride a thousand miles for; you shall be received by one whose touch would make old Nestor young: a terrible plot, a kiss then ravish'd from you by such lips as flow with Nectar, a juicy palm to guide you safe to a private room; but I almost forget, to make the plot more horrid, the retiring Bout, the silver bathing Tub, the Cambrick Rubbers, the imbroidered Quilt, a Bed of Jessemine and Damask Roses, a meer Powder-plot to blow you up: and last of all, a Bedfellow, to whose rare entertainment all these are but fools.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: No more, her breath would warm an Eunuch.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: I knew I should heat him.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: I am flesh and blood, your motion I approve, I'le come.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: My plot's on your life, a base and dangerous woman, farewel Sir.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: I will along too, come pardon my suspition; hear, hear, you shall.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: I am good-natur'd, you may do what you will with me, at twelve I'le be your Convoy.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: I desire not better. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: How do you like my Gown?

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: 'Tis rich, and Court-like.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: My Mother little dreams of my intended flight, and that these are my Nuptial Ornaments.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: I hope so.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: How dully thou answered? dost thou envy Adori,'s noble change?

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: No Madam, I am a little daunted; how to bear your absence, that very thought confounds me; to be devorc'd from all my comfort, can this be born with patience?

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.p: The necessity of my fate commands it; but I vow by my Adorio's love, I pity thee.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: Pity me Madam! a cold charity, you must do more, and help me.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.p: Ha! what said you, I must; is this fit language for a servant?

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: One that would continue your poor servant: Can Mirtilla fit mourning alone, imagining those pleasures which you this blessed night enjoy in the imbraces of your Lord, and mine too, in being yours? shall a stranger sow you up in a sheet to guard that Maidenhead you must pretend to keep, and 'twill become you? shall another do this, and I pine with envy? Pardon me, either let me go with you, or by my life I will discover all.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.p: Thou canst not be so treacherous and cruel.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: Pray don't tempt me, for 'tis resolved.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.p: Prethee Mirtilla be not so violent, I am so taken with thy affection. to me, I will send for thee.

sp.speaker: Mirt
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.p: This very night, by Adorio I will.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: Forgive my boldness past, 'twas iny zeal to serve you.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.p: I thank thee for't.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: You'l keep your word.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.p: Still doubtful.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.l: Now Fortune play thy game,
It shall be hard but I will hit my aim. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: 'Tis eleven by my Watch, the hour appointed, I hear none stirring, some curs'd business keeps her Mother up; I'le walk a little circle, this short delay asflicts me, and I presume to her it is no pleasure. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: What's now to be done? would I were a Bed, I am so sleepy: by this hand I'le break the house for you tomorrow, and she shall be yours by fair or foul means.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: This is the time, I take it, I was ordered by Mirtilla to come; she may perhaps, to take the air, open the Casement.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Would you were in her Cellar, so I were a Bed.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: And looking out, will be a new Star to be gazed on by me with adoration.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Is not here fine fooling? Pox of gazing, and sighing, and peeping, and prying; if you must go to't, put her to the squeak at first sight, and there's an end. [Within.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: 'Tis her voice.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.p: You heard some footing.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: Most certainly.

sp.speaker: Calist
sp.p: Speak low, my love Adorio.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: The darkness befriends me now, most honour'd Madam: Alorio, your servant.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.p: If you are so, I do commend your silence, and this kiss assures you I am wholly yours. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Now miss, and may you be gelt.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: Madam, think on Mirtilla. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I am the fortunatest man in these night works. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: This slowness amazeth me; but here comes some-body.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: Whether shall I fly for succour?

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: These arms shall be a Castle of defence; how her heart beats; take comfort, dear Calista, Adorio loves you, loves you in a Noble ways silence becomes you till we are in safety.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: O blest errour! [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: They have cast me, and say I must wait; but I have found some of their Cordials may be a provocative that was prepared to inable me to perform the Marriage night-duties, up it goes, be it what it will.
