I cannot dread any danger where she is: 'tis pleasant, some restorative to animate their spirits; this nights ramble, with other incumbrances of business, has almost tired me; I feel sleep apprehending me for my neglect of nature, it is too powerful, I must obey. [Sits down.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: 'Uds death, I can't find the sleepy portion that's prepar'd for my Ladies Mother: What Dormouse asleep a ready? much good may women expect from you! what a Devil do you mean to do? my old Lady's coming this way; here's a lump of Sluggard: you lie with a Lady, you lie with a drunken Sow, so you will be taken napping; thy Nose shall pay for this. [Muggulla within.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.p: What's the matter you stay so long? is he fallen asleep? how Camillo, who I took for Adorio! wake him, and bid him be gone.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: I must carry him on my back then, for any way else he is not fit to go: is he not dead? cold by this hand. [Falls out of the Chair.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.p: O, O! call in his man, let him remove him; he has got some hurt in his night rambles, and comes here to die, to have the shame fall upon me.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Stark dead! are you sure? you have held him at hard service; I'le be hanged if Muggulla has not thrown him on his back, for she's an old Swinger at these sports.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.p: Leave your idle discourse, and convey him away.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Out of the house you can't carry him, your Mother must see it done.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.p: Search him Calandrino, if he be not wounded any where.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: O here's large wound! how it is swelled! this must, this must be cunningly drawn out, should it break, 'twould strangle him: O what a deal of foul matter's here! this has been a long time of gathering: here's a gash too in the Rimb of his Belly, it may have matter in't; he was a cholerick man I see; what comes from him is as yellow as Gold: how, troubled with the Stone? I'le cut you for this. His Pocket, then his Purse.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p:
It must be so, he has drank the sleepy portion which was designed.
for your Mother, so that we'll lay him in the great Chest in the next Room, may be when he awakes we may have a more fit opportunity to let him out.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I had rather bury him quick than part with my purchase; let his Ghost walk, I care not: who's that? where's the Chest? I am afraid her calling should wake him. [Calista, Mugg. within.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: A shrill voice, it comes with the wind.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Then I'le take this way.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.p: Why, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Because I'le trust my heels before all the winds in the Sky; we are far wiser than our Gransi •• s were; and thus I'le prove it, they say, haste to the beginning of a feast, there I am with'um; but to the end of a fray, that's Apocryphal, 'tis Canonical, not to come there at all: after a Storm, there are still some drops behind.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Pure fear has made the fool a Philosopher; come, help away with him.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: He's wondrous heavy, but the Porter's paid, there's the comfort. [Lays him in the Chest, and falls upon him.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.p: Away, my Mother will come out.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Now if he wakes not, I am made for ever;
And if he does, 'twas but a fools endeavour. [Exit.

div.head: ACT III.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: WAs ever man thus crost?

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: So blest I hop't to have been; this is the finest wild Chace.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: What's that you mutter?

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: A short prayer, that you may find my Lady, your wished-for love, though I am lost for ever. [Camillo in the Chest.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Calandrino, light a Candle, 'tis horrible dark.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: O me! what's that? from whence could that come?

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: I don't know, may be the old Lady has discovered our coming.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Draw the Curtains, I say, you Rascal; what a Devil do you mean to do? Adorio will get there before I shall come.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: If it be a Spirit, it made use of my name; 'tis somewhere in the room.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: I am afraid, yet dare not stir, for fear you should be found here.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Sirrah, I say Calista made the appointment, and would you have me fail her, Rogue, Dog, Devil?

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: It must be some Imp, it has the Devil so frequently in's mouth.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: I tremble to think on't.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: 'Zounds, I'le stay for this damn'd Dog no longer. [Rises out of the Chest.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: My courage fails me, doubting 'tis not mortal. [Both run out.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: Oh the Devil! the Devil!

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p:
What can this mean? that seem'd to be Adorio going out; how came I to have this wooden Tenement? this room they left me in; now
dare not I call Muggulla, because I am ignorant how matters go in the house.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.p: What noise was that I heard?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Madam, I know not, nor what caused it; but I am in as much doubt as they could be in fear, how by what means I was laid in this Chest; Providence I must ever bless that it proves so well, since you allow on't.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.p: What's this? 'twas necessity made me so careful of your proceedings; now you'r at liberty, I desire your absence.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Madam, 'tis strange, but for once I'le withdraw, and render you my hearty thanks for the care you have used to preserve me safe, and your own Honour. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.p: My lov'd Adorio, though disasterous chance has made me lament thy absence, it pays me ample satisfaction that I am now possest of thee.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: Away: have you plaid your game with him, and now come to me to retrieve your appetite? I must reassume my ancient Faith, all Woman-kind is false. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.p: False man, but more treacherous woman, 'tis apparent you joyntly have conspired against my weakness, for which expect my just anger; reply not. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.l: She commands both, one is enough for me,
If I be false, Love is a treachery. [Exit.

div.stage: Enter Calandrino, a Bottle of Wine.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Good speed on all sides, 'tis main strong Wine: O the yauns that Muggulla will make! look to your Stern, dear Mistress, and steer right: Stay, let me see, I'le try her by thy Nose first, for if she be a right Sow, sure she'll find it: yonder she comes; O how she holds up her Nose like a Jennet in the wind of a grass Mare!

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: 'Tis Wine, I'm sure 'tis Wine, excellent strong Wine, very good Wine; this way too.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: How true she hunts, I'le make the Train a little stronger. [Spills Wine.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Stronger and stronger still, still blessed Wine.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Now she hunts hot.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: This way it went sure.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Now she's at a cold sent: O well hunted! that's she! that's she!

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: O if I could but see it! O what a precious sent it has! but handle it, and then but taste it.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Now I'le come in view.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Still 'tis stronger: Calandrino, what hast thou got there? answer to the point man.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: 'Tis Wine, Madam Muggulla, sweet Sweet-wine.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Is this a drink for Slaves to tipple on? dear sweet Sweet-wine come hither; give me a Bottle thou most debauched Drudge.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: With no small pains I purchased this on purpose for you, to shew how willing I am to give you all my service.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: I will give thee more: there, kiss my hand on't.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I thank you cleanlily for your dirty favour; how rank it smells?

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: By your leave sweet Bottle, and sweet Sweet-wine, I now come to thee, hold your Cap under.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: She sucks off her sweet Sweet-wine, sweet, sweet, sweetly: how do you like it?

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Hold up your Cap again Sir, and now come kiss me: I'le be your friend at a word Sir; come, drink to me.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I must not be too bold with this liquor.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Here's to thee then; 'tis for thy good, 'tis confest; nay, 'tis naught for thee, and may chance to make you break out, and spoil thy complexion: 'tis excellent for me, I have a cold Stomach, and the Wine▪

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Blows out at both ends.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Kiss me again, thou shalt kiss Calista too: again cherish thy lips, I'le show thee all.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Bless my eyes!

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Enter all the secrets in my Country Commands, and thou shalt be my Heir, and I'le leave thee Heaven knows what.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I believe so; but I shall never know.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Then you shall have my Daughters two sweet Wenches, but you must commit with me first, and show yourself a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Excellent Mistress Muggulla, I thank you heartily.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: And prethee, Calandrino, take heed of being overtaken with too much drink, 'tis a lamentable fin: O 'tis a damnable thing to be drunk, Heaven can't endure it! And hark you, one thing I would have you do, knock my Husband on the Head, for he's an errant Puppy, and cannot perform; why, where the Devil is this foolish Bottle?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: O how her Husband would cry, did he know how drunk she will be with this Wine!

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Who's that talks of Wine there?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I think 'tis your Husband at the door.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Bring him before me, I'le beat him damnably; nay, break the Bottle about his Pate, then tye it to his Tail, and all the Dogs in the Town shall follow him: Come, sit down, and let us propound a modest question, to see who is drunkest, you or I.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: The very sent has disabled me; what's the question?

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Whether Whitehall or Cheapside be nearest Whetstones Park? or what's the natural reason, why a woman should long to make her Husband a Cuckold? Bring the Curate, that learn'd Philosopher, that found out a Pudden had two ends, let him with his Jacob's Staff discover what is the third part of three farthings, three half-pence being the half, and I am satisfied.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: You blow me down with your Learning.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Too much for that Bull-head, my Husband: Hang him, he's but the shadow of a man of action, a debauch'd Puppy, let him sleep, and thou shalt sleep with me.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: You are a very loving worthy woman, I had as live she had said I should have lain in the Hog-sty.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Not a word of Wine Callandrino, or any thing like Wine, or any thing concerning Wine, or by, or from, or with Wine: Come, lead me like a Countess. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: Then it seems you ever have affected me.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: Should my Lady stand by and hear't, and in her sudden fury kill me for't, I durst not Sir deny it; nor is it me alone, but all our Sex, I think, stand bound to be enamoured of you.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: O my Fate! I am justly punished for my defended wantonness: I that scorn'd the Mistress when she sought me, now I would upon my knees receive her, am become a Prey unto her Bond-woman: thou art one of those aim to be the wrong way Ladifi'd: Was there no forward Page or Footboy in the Town to do the feat, but I must be chosen for the Executioner? how durst you hope it?

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Kings sometimes leave Calveare, Salmon, and eat Sprats; in modesty I dare speak no more.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: How cam'st thou to my hands?

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: My Lady being slipt aside in the dark, fearing her Mother should find out the appointment, and, as I thought, quitted the house, thanks to the darkness of the night, running after her, I run into your arms; and I had wrong'd my breeding near the Court, had I refused it.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: You expect to reap the Harvest of your Flattery but your hopes will be blasted: I assure you I am tired, I must sleep; you could lie down too.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: Willingly, so you please to use me.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: Use thee?

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: As your Pillow Sir, I dare presume no farther.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: Well, sit down.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: I am ready Sir. [Sits down.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: So nimble.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: Love is active, nor would be a slow thing, rest securely; Sir, on my Maidenhead, I'le not ravish you. [Lays bis head in her lap.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: For one so fair, I'le trust you.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: Let all the joys of rest dwell on his Eye-lids; let no dream disturb your soft and gentle slumbers: I cannot sing, but I'le talk you asleep she snores already: I am all fire, I can no longer forbear, I'le touch his lips, I am intranced; our Fancy, some say, in sleep works stronger, I will prove how far mine will work. [Sleeps.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p:
My Bones ake with sleeping on the Bench, and I am exceeding cold after my heat, I must seek out a mere convenient Truckle-Bed: Ha! do I
dream? No, no, I wake; as I live Adorio in a handsome Wenches Lap: O Whorson! you are better accommodated than I have been with my old drunken She-goat; I'le call my Master and his Mistress to this Pageant, this may work more upon her than all he can say: Master, Madam, come forth.

sp.speaker: Cam
sp.p: Well, what's your hasty business? what have you seen the Devil? or how?

sp.speaker: Cala.
sp.p: No Boy, no; but here are some that you thought not of.

sp.speaker: Cala.
sp.p: The Idol you used to worship.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.p: Is this Mirtilla? I was but a Cloak to his intended Villany.

sp.speaker: Cala.
sp.p: I knew 'twould take.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I'le not kill him sleeping, but if you please, I'le wake him, and then make him fall a Sacrifice to your just anger.

sp.speaker: Cala.
sp.p: No, reserve your blood for a better use.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.p: My fond love is turn'd to extreme hatred, his very sight is odious.

sp.speaker: Cala.
sp.p: I have thought of a punishment for 'um, and then leave him to his Harlotry; if she prove not torture enough, hold me an Ass: I saw their Horses not far off, I'le cut their Girts and Bridles, and turn 'um out to the Road.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.p: In his Hat he wears a Jewel, which this faithless Strumpet, as a Salary of her Lust, deceiv'd me of; he shall not keep it to my disgrace, nor will I stir till I have it.

sp.speaker: Cala.
sp.p: I am not a profest nimmer, yet l'le make a shift: by your leave Sir, 'tis restitution; pray bear witness I do not steal it; here 'tis.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.p: Take it not as a Mistress's favour, but a strong assurance I am your Wise.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: O Heaven!

sp.speaker: Cala.
sp.p: Pray in the Church: let's away: have you not been billing in the Hay, and so deserved this unexpected favour?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: You'r pleasant Sir, come, will you walk. Exit Cam. Calista, Calandrino.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: As thou art a Gentleman kill me not basely, give me leave to draw my Sword. [Adorio starts up, his Hat falls off.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: What's the matter? do you dream?

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: A fearful one I dream't, methought Camillo's Sword was at my Throat, Calista frowning by, commanding him, as he desired my favour her favour to strike off my head.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: Meer imagination; here's your Hat.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: But where's my Jewel?

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: I lookt upon when you slept.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: What's come on't then? Restore it; thou hast it; force me not to search thee

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: Search me.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: You was before your Ladies entertainment a Night-walker, traded in picking of Pockets, when tame Cully's charmed with your prostitute fluttery, vouchsafed to imbrace you.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: Love, give place to anger; wer't thou an Emperour, 'twas false; in thy teeth l'le tell it thee, steal what I present.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: This will not do, though thou hast swallow'd it, I'le rip thee up, but I'le recover it.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: Help, help, help, murther!

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: What, a new plot; let me have it, I say.

sp.speaker: Cala.
sp.p: Hey day! at it afore folks! fie for shame; you are a hot Cock of the Game.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: O me wretched Maid! [Mirtilla swoonds.

sp.speaker: Cala.
sp.p: Hold her up, she'll fall again before her time else: Come, come, Mistress, the man's a well-timber'd man, he's whole Chested, and may be a little forward with his work, in time you will make him ride more moderate; then if he prove not of the right strain, Cuckold him first, and after make a Capon of him, never fear a Rape, fear him not.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.p: Methought I heard some Womens shrieks; what, was it Calandrino?

sp.speaker: Cala.
sp.p: Nothing, only Master Adorio would force her to say one Lesson too often over, which is a fault I seldome heard a woman complain on, to refuse that sort of exercise.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.p: My too fond Love Adorio, I have for ever banisht from my heart, and in lieu, the Holy man has given me to Camillo, in whose worthy love Calista must be safe.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Calista, you are all goodness.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: Nay then Adorio be a man, I see the Diamond; Mirtilla forgive me, thy honest vertuous love I will repay; take me, and dispose of me as you think fit.

sp.speaker: Cala.
sp.p: Chain him up; and when you feel the loving hour coming on you, let him recreate you, and then to his Cell again, in a short time you'l find him a sober Companion.

sp.speaker: Mirt,
sp.p: My heart can't let me give a denial; take me your faithful Handmaid.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: O who shall take me! for something has taken my Husband, the Fates be blest: but whether above or below he's gone, that matters not.

sp.speaker: Cala.
sp.p: O! to Heaven he must go; you have been always a careful woman in that kind: Well, you and I will never marry; for now we may drink and sleep together without controul, since that Ram-headed Block is removed.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Lord, I am so troubled with the Teago, I believe it is because I drink but little Wine.

sp.speaker: Ado.
sp.p: 'Tis a raw humour blows up in your head, you don't take it often enough.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: 'T may be so: truly Sir, I don't drink above a Bottle in an hour.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: How many's that a day? Mrs. Muggnlla, l'le be your Doctor, and administer effectually, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Cam
sp.p: But are your Dancers ready?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: All things ready: pray seat your selves, that I may have room to perform matters of admiration: let your eye be riveted to my heels, and miss not a hair, breadth of my footing: our Dance has a most melodious note, and I command you to have Ears like Hares this night for our Masters Honour, and something of my Worship; your reward is to be drunk blind, like Moles, in the Wine-cellar, and though you never see after, 'tis the better: and do you hear wire-string Cats guts men, and strong-breath'd Hoe boys, for the credit of your Calling; twang it perfectly, as you would read your N • ck verse; marshal your selves in the Rear, the Van is ours: Come, Mrs. Muggulla, imagine it our wedding day. [A Rustick Dance.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Adorio, Let us forget all but honourable friendship, and let that last till Time shall be no more.
sp.l: Now may all here, that love, as they are Friends,
To our good fortunes find like prosperous ends, [Exeunt.

l.hi: OUr Habits and our Acting such appears,
Like weather-beaten weary Travellers:
Who have endur'd more then may here be told,
From Eastern blasts and sharper Northern cold.
Which keeps our sadded Hearts in deep suspence,
Wanting a place to fix our Residence.
Yet if these Radiant Beauties will but please
To smile on our Endeavours, 'twill much ease
Our Cares, abate our Feares: well knowing then,
Their Influence creates Favours in those Men:
Whose noble Bounty and Compassion may,
Transform our sable Night to chearful Day.
So by your Goodness with your mercy mixt,
We wandring Planets may in time be fixt.
AS timerous Crack with Bayliffs close beset,
Knowing her Rigging cann't discharg her Debt;
Scrues up invention to the highest pin,
To make a Trap to catch the Devil in.
Melting in tears with looks half lust half love,
Hoping the hot-rein'd ravenous Foe to move;
Sighs in his Bosom, Sir, if you'l be kind,
I would do, you know what, you know my mind.
The goatish hell-hound boyling in a Feaver,
Cry's damn the Plantiff, swears he'le never leave her.
Imagin now the feat is done, and she
Is gone and clapt him for his Courtesie.
I just like her, have ventur'd out to you;
Could I but wheedle and o're come you too:
Then like a loving and a fearful Elf,
I'd send you sound away, be clapt my self.

div.p: THE POLITICK WHORE: OR, THE CONCEITED CUCKOLD

LONDON: Printed for Dan. Browne at the Black Swan and Bible without Temple-Bar, Dan. Major at the Hand and Scepter over against S. Dunstan's Church in Fleetstreet, and James Vade at the Cock and Sugar Loaf near S. Dunstan's Church in Fleetstreet. 1680.

list.head: Actors Names.
list.item: SIr Cornelius Credulous, a Fond Husband.
Sir Isaac Jealousie, always doubtful of his Wife.
Mutchcraft, a Gentleman disguis'd, Gallant to Policia.

list.head: Women.
list.item: Policia, Wife to Cornelius, the Politick Whore.

div.head: THE POLITICK WHORE: OR, The CONCEITED CUCKOLD.
ACT I.

sp.speaker: Isa.
Fido.
sp.p: By your white hand, I swear 'twas only so.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Poyson of Toads between you.

sp.speaker: Innocentia.
sp.p: Fido you have well satisfied me.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Insatiate Whore, could not I satisfie you? I shall commit a murder if I stay: I'le go forge Thunder for you; what Plague can transcend a whorish Wife, and a persidious Friend, Traitor to Truth and Friendship, I could rip out that blushing Hypocrite, thy Heart.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: What means this Fury?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Can you spell Stag, Sir? 'tis four letters with two Horns: get you from my fury, for fear of greater mischief.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: Thou yellow Fool.

sp.speaker: Ino.
sp.p: I would you would instruct me, Sir, but how to understand all this.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Did ever mortal see so foul a guilt stand underneath a look so innocent.

sp.speaker: Ino.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: You Whore. [Kicks her.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: Were't not for looking to the Lady, I'de call you to strict account.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Look to her, hang her: let me now send her to the Devil, with the scarlet Robe of Sin she's lapt in, that men should ever marry, and when we lay our Heads in womens laps, rise up with Horns.

sp.speaker: Ino.
sp.p: With patience hear me, good Sir.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Yes, and go make Potgims.

sp.speaker: Ino.
sp.p: 'Tis late, and sleep will do good, Sir.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Why do you think I'm mad?

sp.speaker: Ino.
sp.p: I hope not, Sir Isaac.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Then you lye, I am made Horn-mad; I shall be acted at both the Theaters: Oh he that can believe a sleep's secure
sp.l: In a false Friends Oaths or a bad Wives Arms,
Trusts Circes Witchcrafts, or Calipsos Charms. [Exit Isa. Fido.

sp.speaker: Ino.
sp.p: Oh Sir Isaac, how far am I in love with affliction, because it calls thee Father:
sp.l: Oh Jealousie, Loves Eclipse, thou art in thy Disease,
A wild mad Patient, wondrous hard to please. [Exit.

div.stage: Enter Sir Cornelious Credelus, and Mocko.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: My negligence deserves just blame, and how my Policia will take it I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: As Snuff does you, by the Nose. [Enter Fido,

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: Sir Credelus your Servant; I hope your fair Lady's well.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: See, see she and her zealous School-master: I'le put you all upon her anon. [Enter Policia, Muchcraft.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: Then I shall have my turn.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: You are a wondrous happy man in one so vertuous.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Nay, you shall have no Sir Isaacs of me, I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: Nor no Inocentia of your wife, I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Sweet Chick I come to take leave of thee, for I am going to see a Ship launch'd, you may walk and see Sir Isaac Jealousie's Lady.

sp.speaker: Poli.
sp.p: Alass she's too merry for my company.

sp.speaker: Fido,
sp.p: Too merry; I have seen her sad, but very seldom merry.

sp.speaker: Poli.
sp.p: I mean Sir, that she can walk to the Change, tell Tales, run in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: Why then your Ladyship may hold your tongue, say nothing, and walk in the Orchard.

sp.speaker: Poli.
sp.p: She can drink a glass of Wine not alayd with Water.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: Then you may drink a cup of Water without Wine.

sp.speaker: Poli.
sp.p: Nay if a Gentleman comes to her House she'll let him kiss her, though a stranger.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: Why a modest Woman may be kist by accident, yet not give the least touch to her Reputation.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Well said, touch her home.

sp.speaker: Poli.
sp.p: Nay, but they may not; she that will kiss, they say, will do worse I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: Why Madam I have seen you kist, may be against your will.

sp.speaker: Poli.
sp.p: You may be sure 'twas against my will, though I have been kist indeed.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: There's nothing in that can be against a Womans will, and I dare be sworn, if my Lady kist but one man, 'tis because we can't do with all.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Nay that I know to be true, therefore she shall only kiss you Fido at this time; nay, come kiss her, and we are gone.

sp.speaker: Poli.
sp.p: Nay pray Sir Cornelious, 'tis against my customes.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: I care not; let naturals love customes, my humour's my humour: look ye she spits, kiss her close.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: The nearer the bone, the sweeter the flesh, Lady.

sp.speaker: Poli.
sp.p: How now sawce-box.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: Why Madam, I had but my turn, are you angry at that?

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Sirah, go and call a pair of Oars, Muchcraft, prethee stay thou at home with thy Lady, make her merry, get your Instrument ready, this melancholly will spoil her; make her laugh but heartily before I come home, and I'le give you a Lease of forty Crowns per annum.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Can you tell whether she be ticklish or no Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Oh infinitely ticklish.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: I'le deserve your Lease before you come home again I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: And thou shalt have't I faith boy.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: Sir, there is a boat ready for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Oh that's well, farewel my dear Policia. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Fido,
sp.p: Adieu Madam, and when so e're I marry, Fortune turn no worse Card to me than you are. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: And when so e're I marry, Venus send me a Card may save Fortune a labour, and turn up her self. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: What made him leave you behind.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: To lye with your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: How: Why in the Bed, or on the Bed, or without the Bed.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Why how now Muchcraft.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Why, the plain truth on't is, I must lye with you.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Why, Muchcraft?

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: And I know too, that you will lye with me.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Nay, but Muchcraft.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: A Pox of Muchcraft; I am neither Much Craft, nor Little Craft, but a Barkshire Gentleman, that has heard of your Beauty; assum'd this Name and Fortune, saught this Service, and tell you truly what I guess you.

sp.speaker: Polic,
sp.p: You will not Ravish me, Muchcraft?

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: No; but unravel you, in two lines Experience writ lately.
sp.l: Extreams in Vertue, are but Clouds to Vice;
She'll do i'th' dark, who is i'th' day too nice.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Indeed you do not well to belye me thus.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Come, I'le lye with thee Wench, and make all well again: your Husband swears no Woman can deceive him, and 'twere well done to cozen his confidence.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Truly, Muchcraft, some Women would do't.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Who can you chuse more convenient to practice with than me, whom he doats on? Where shall a man find a Friend but at home? so break one Proverbs Pate, and give the other a Plaister. Is't a Match, ha?

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Well, for once it is; but and you do any more, indeed I'le tell my Husband.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: But when shall this once be, now?

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Now! no indeed, Muchcraft, it shall be soon, at Night my Knight comes home.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Then, how is't possible?

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Possible; Women can make any of these things possible, Muchcraft: many casualties may cross us, but soon at night my Cornelius I'm sure will be sleepy after his hard drinking; and when well drench'd in Wine, he sleeps in his Cloaths on the Bed so sound, Bells would not wake him were they rung in the Chamber.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Then he'll never dream of our Intrigue.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Now Mocko that makes him merry in his Chamber, shall, when the Candle's out, and he asleep, bring you into the Chamber.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: But will he be secret?

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Will he, good Soul! I am not to try him now.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.l: 'Uds-foot, this is brave,
My Knights kind Fool is my cunning Ladies Knave.
sp.p: But pray, how then?

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: When Mocko has brought you to the Bed, give me but softly a touch, I'le rise, and follow you into the next Chamber: But truly and you do not use me kindly, I shall cry out, and spoil all.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Use you kindly; was ever Lady used cruelly i'th' dark? do you but prepare Mocko and your Maid, let me alone with her Mistress; about Eleven I desire to be expected.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: And till the Clock strike Twelve I lye alone.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Now you dare kiss.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Once with a Friend, or so; yet you may take two, Muchcraft.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: My Cast is Ames-Ace then.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Deuce-Ace had got the Game.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Well, if you'l set, I'le throw at all.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: If you throw out, then down you fall. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Here, miserable Innocentia, let thy sorrows take breath; unto this House where Gentlemen lodge I was directed, but I here discover strange actions carried on in this House: Great Persons, but not good, here nightly Revel in Surfeits, and in Riots; and yet the next day the place appears a Sanctuary, rather than Sins foul Receptacle: these ways have to me still been strangers.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Yonder she walks mumbling to her self, my Lord Generous has cast an eye of liking on her, and you win her but for him, your House bears the Bell away; acost her quaintly.

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: I warrant thee Drudgeo, I can effect wonders of more weight than a Maiden-head: Have I ruin'd so many Cities, Citadels, to let in Court-Martialists, and shall this Country-Cottage hold out? I were more fit for a Cart than Coach then 'lfaith. How now Philice, how do you this morning?

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Well, I thank so good a Landlady.

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: But hark you Philice, is the Door close Drudgeo?

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.p: As an Usurers Conscience: Madge was coming in, till she saw the Door shut upon her.

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: I'le set Madge about her business, and I come to her: Is here any work for her, with a mischief to her? We shall have Eves-droppers, shall we?

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Honour guard me, how I tremble.

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: Come hither Mistress Philice: Fie, how you let your hair hang about your Ears too: How do you like my House, Phil.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Well, exceeding well.

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: Nay, I know a Woman may rise here in a Month, if she will her self: but truth's truth, I know you see something, as they say, and so forth. Did you see the Gallant was here last night till Twelve?

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Which of them mean you? here was many.

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: Which; he in the white Feather, that skipp'd in the Gallery: Was it white, Drudgeo?

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.p: As a Ladies hond, by this five fingers.

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: White; no, no, 'twas a Tawny; now I remember.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.p: As a Gypsie; by this Hand it lookt white by Candle-light though.

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: That fine Lord is call'd my Lord Generous, Phil. a great man, I'le assure you Phil.

sp.speaker: Innoc,
sp.p: His Excellent Carriage spoke him of Noble Birth.

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: And this Lord loves you Phillis.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Now Heaven defend me!

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: What, from a Lord? marry come up with a Murrian; from whence came you tro', ha?

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.p: Thus nice Madge was at first, if you remember.

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: I would have you know Huswife, I could have taken my Coach, and fetch'd him one of the best Pieces in London, and her Husband should have look'd after me, that his Neighbours might have noted, and cry'd, Farewel Naunt, commend me to my Unkle.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.p: And yet from these perfum'd fortunes, Heaven defend me.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Perfum'd indeed.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.p: Perfum'd; I am a Pander, a Rogue, that hangs together like a Beggars Rags by Geometry, if there was not three Ladies fwore yesterday that my Mistress perfum'd the Coach; so they were fain to unbrace the Side-parts to take in fresh Air.

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: He tells you true, I keep no company, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: But have you so many several Women to answer so many men that come?

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.p: I'le answer that by Demonstration: Have you not observed the variation of a Cloud, sometimes 'twill be like a Lyon, sometimes like a Horse, sometimes a Castle, and yet still a Cloud.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.p: Why so can we make one Wench one day look like a Country Weneh, another day like a Citizens Wife, another day like a Lady, and yet still be a Crack.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: VVhat shall become of me? Oh the sad Curse
Of goodness, to leave one woe for a worse.

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: Come Phil. let's in, and be merry. [Exeunt.

div.head: ACT II.
div.stage: Sir Cornelius asleep on a Bed in his Cloaths, Policia in Bed; to them, Moeko leading in Muchcraft.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: SOftly sweet Mocko; are we in the Chamber yet?

sp.speaker: Mook.
sp.p: Within a yard of my Lady, and ye can be quiet.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Art sure Sir Cornelius is asleep?

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: I know not, I'le go and ask him.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: No, no, no, do not awake him, we are undone then, man.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, now I see Cuckold-making is as ticklish a profession as Cunney-catching: my Lord was so paid with Healths, he's fast enough.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: But still I pursue wonder, why my Lady should prescribe this strange, nay wonderous desperate way to her desires.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: Is that a question to ask now? would you would grope out the Bed, for I sleep in my talk I am sure of that. [Sir Cornelius Coughs.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: We are lost for ever: did he not cough?

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: 'Tis nothing but the last Cup comes up in stewd broth; if ever you make true Whoremaster burn me: sea-sick before you come in the salt-water; let me go in your stead.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: No I'le venture, stood a Gulph between belching up a Tempest. O valiant Lust! how resolute thou goest to Acts unjust. Mocko good night: desire drowns fear in presuppos'd delight.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: Turn of your left hand, 'twill lead you to the Devil, to my Lady, I should say presently. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Let me see: Four steps on the left hand. I have the Bed, and on this side she lies: Ud's foot there's a beard; but all's well yet; she lies on this side sure: I have her; 'tis her Hand, I know the touch, it melts me into passion: I have much ado to contain my wild desires: as the wind strains in caverns lock'd, so through my big swoln vains my blood cuts capers.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: 'Tis I.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Fortunate Muchcraft, that was wrapt in his Mothers Smock.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Give me your hand.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: There 'tis: I melt already.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Sir, Husband; Sir Cornelius, awake.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: I am lost for ever, Madam.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Sir Cornelius, Husband.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: If I pull too hard, I shall pull her out of the bed too.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Why Knight, will you not awake.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: What's the matter, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: How I dwindle.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Pray hear me Sir; I cannot sleep till you have resolv'd me one thing.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: What is that Sweetheart?

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Of all men which do you love best?

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: That's a strange question to ask at midnight; why Muchcraft.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: And that same false Muchcraft in your absence most leudly tempted me to wrong your bed.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Was ever woodcock cateh'd thus.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Oh Rogue, Ple cut his throat sleeping.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Nay I have fitted him finely.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Now, now, now, now I am splted.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: I seem'd Sweetheart to consent to him.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: A pox of shammings: I were best confess and beg pardon.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: And to make him sure for your revenge, I appointed about this hower, the door left open on purpose

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Ah.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: To meet me in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: All's well again.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Now Sweetheart, if you would but steal down, you might catch him, and snap the Fool very finely.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Oh Heavens what a wench have I of thee! I'le take my Rapier, and the night being dark, I'le speak like thee, as if thou had kept thy word: O Villain, I shall have you; do you lie still, and I'le bring thee his Heart for thy Monkeys breakfast.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: And would you part unkindly and not kiss me?

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: I have no more manners than a Goose: Farewell
sp.l: My chast delicious Girl: what may his life
Be compar'd to, that meets with such a Wife! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Hist Mocko.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: Hear Boy.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Go meet him in the Garden—and hark.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: Excellent: I'le play my Lady I warrant you. Well, I may hope for a Squiers Place, my Father was a Costermonger. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p:
Well now I see, he who would know Hells Crafts in her may
read it, in brief put him to School
sp.l: (Would cheat the Devil of's right,)
To a dainty smooth-fac'd Hypocrite. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Why here's a Wife Mocko!

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: Ay Sir, to discover upon the pinch to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Oh what Fortunes we loving Husbands meet with!

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: Ay Sir, Fortune's in the fashion of Hay Forks.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Mocko, thou shalt hardly see a harsh Fellow have such a Wife, such a fortunate Wedding.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: He'll go to hanging as soon.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: No, no; we loving souls have all the luck: There's Sir Isaac Jealous, what ado there is about his Wife; and now she's fled: and what has brought her to't, but his dogged usage of her.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: Nay she never liv'd a good day with him.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Therefore the whole Town rings of the winding of his Horns. Had he such a wife as I: what a Villain did I entertain, to teach her Musick; he had done her no good since he came, that I see.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: Hang him: he has made her a little perfect in Prick-Song, that's all; and it may be she had skill in that before you married her.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: She could sing at first sight by this hand, Mocko: but hark, I hear somebody.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: 'Tis he sure: he has a dreaming Whoremasters pace. Pray let me practise my Ladies Part, and counterfeit for her.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Canst thou imitate to the life?

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: Can I? Oh wicked Muchcraft.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Admirable thou shalt do't.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: Pray be you ready with your Rapier to spit him then; and Ple watch him a good turn, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Here they are: If Mocko now comes off with his Part neatly, the Comedy passes bravely. Who's there—Madam?

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: I think this place lies open to the Air, Muchcraft.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Delicate Mocko.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: And truly there's a great Dew fallen to night, the Grass is very wet.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Sweet-tongu'd Rogue.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: Come Muchcraft,
sp.l: And let us sport our selves in yonder Rushes;
And being set, I'le sinother thee with bushes.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Oh Villain.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Here my Lady; it is enough my Master has now a Friend in these days that dares be honest.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: Nay for thy Master, he's a meer Coxcomb, Muchcraft.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Out Rogue.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: 'Tis but your bad desires that tell you so: can I contain a Heart, or can that Heart harbour a thought of injury against him, under whose Wing I safely stretch my Pinions: has he not nobly entertain'd me? Stand I not next neighbour, save your self, unto his Heart?

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Ay, by this Hand dost thou.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: And shall I requite him thus? No Lady, no.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Brave Muchcraft.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: I am too wise to fall in love with Wo, much less with Woman: I but took advantage of my Masters absence for your Tryal, Madam, for fear some Fellow, far hotter-rein'd then I, might have sought and sped; and I should be loth a Master so loving,

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Shalt have five Leases, by these Fingers.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.l: Should have a Lady false.
Back Lady to your yet unblemish'd Bed;
Preserve your Honour, and your Lords Calves Head.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: Well Muchcraft you had been better: if I do not tell your Master of this.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: He has put him to't now.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Then I am lost for ever: You'll turn it all on me I know; but ere I'le live to wrong so good a man, or stand the mark unto your malice, I will first fall on my Sword, and perish.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Hold, hold man.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Ha; who are you?

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: One that has more humanity in him than to see a proper Fellow cast himself away, I warrant thee: 'tis I, 'tis I man; I have heard all.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: And 'twas I have playd my Lady, to have snapt you.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Has she then been so good to tell you? Now I am worse afflicted than before, that she should thus out-run me in this race of honesty.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Nay, she has hobb'd thee bravely: She has a thousand of these tricks, I faith man; but howsoever, what I have found thee, I have found thee: Hark in thy ear: Thou shalt have five Leases, and my own Nagg, when thou hast a mind to ride.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Let me deserve it first.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Thou shalt have 'um, I know what I do, I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: I joy in such a Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Nay, there's a couple of you, for a Wife and a Friend: thou shalt be no more my Servant; I had thought to have made thee my Steward, but thou art too honest for the place that's the truth on't.

sp.speaker: Mocko.
sp.p: His superfluity is my necessity; pray let me have it Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: I will talk with thee to morrow: Mocko, thou shalt have something too, but I'le to Bed: honest Muchcraft, the dearest must part, I see; I will so hug the sweet Rascal that thinks every hour ten, till I come yonder: Good-night Muchcraft; to Bed Mocko:
sp.l: VVhat delight in life,
Can equal such a Friend, and such a VVife. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: Go; and a Cartload of Horns go with thee. But shall I not be thought on for my nights Service?

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Why look you: pray forget not you had something.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: Well: and pray do you remember I had nothing.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Nothing; what's that?

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: Nothing before I had something I mean; so you are welcome from Utopia.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: You are very nimble; Sir, good morrow. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Did ever Chronicle match this couple?

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: You make me wonder, that both should meet in one resolved goodness unknown to one another.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: There lies the Jest on't: Sirrah Mocko, come hither.
I do but think, had she met him in the Garden, how she would have ratled him.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: Ay, and ruffled him too Sir; the Camomile would have been better for it many a day after.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: Such an honest-minded Servant, where shall one find?

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Servant; my sworn brother, man: he's too honest for an Office, he'le ne're thrive in't.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: A Wife; why she's a Saint, one that beares a good sound Soul about her.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: Yes, when she wears her new Shoes.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Where is she Mocko?

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: Walking a turn or two in the Garden with Muchcraft, shall, I go call, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: No, no, no; 'tis pitty to part 'um, they are so well match'd: What are they doing?

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: Why Sir, she was weeping to him; she heard this morning that her Confessor Father Joseph was dead.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Why now shan't we have her eat a bit these five days.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: She'le Munch the more in a Corner, that's her Fasts.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Nay, do but judge Fido: Whereas most Dames go but once a month, some twice a quarter, and once a year to Confession, and that upon constraint too; she never misses twice a week.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: 'Tis a sign she keeps all well at home; they are even with the World, that so keep touch with Heaven.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: See where she comes! Why how now Chick, weeping so fast, this is the fault of most of our Ladies; Painting, weeping for their sins, I should say, spoils their Faces.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Sweet Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Look, look, loving Soul, he weeps for company.

sp.speaker: Mocko.
sp.p: And I shall laugh out-right by and by.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Oh that good man!

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Why, Bird.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: Be patient.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: And wou'd he go to Heaven without me?

sp.speaker: Mocko.
sp.p: It may be he knew not your mind, Madam.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: He knew my mind well enough.

sp.speaker: Mocko.
sp.p: Why then, it may be, he knew you cou'd not hold out for the Journey; pray do not set us all a crying. [Weeps.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Prethee, sweet Birds-n'ye, be content.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Yes, yes, be content; when you two leave my company, no one comes near me, so that were not for simple modest Muchcraft here.

sp.speaker: Mocko.
sp.p: As modest as a Gib-Cat at Mid-night.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: That sometimes reads to me some vertuous Treatise; were it not for him, I might go look content: but 'tis no matter, no body cares for me.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Good Fido, help to comfort her. [Weeps.

sp.speaker: Mocko.
sp.p: Now is the Devil a writing an Encomium upon cunning Cuckoldmakers.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: You have been harsh to her of late, I fear Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: By this hand I turn'd not from her all last-night; what shou'd a man do?

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: Come, this is but a sweet obedient Shower, to bedew the lamented Grave of her old Father.

sp.speaker: Mocko.
sp.p: He thinks the Devil's dead too.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Prethee Muchcraft walk a turn in the Garden, to get her a Stomack to her Dinner; we'll be with you presently.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Nay, when you please; but why should I go from you?

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Loving Soul, prethee take her away.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Pray let me kiss you first: come, Muchcraft, no body cares for us.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Well, she's a precious Creature. [Much. as they go out, kisses her.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: 'Uds death, he kist her at the door: Have I found you Lady? But mum.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Hark you Mocko, you must go and invite my Lady Meriday to Sup with us; tell her my Lady is never well but in her company.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: What if you invited Sir Isaac Jealous, he's so melancholly since his Wife and he are parted.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Do as you are bid, let him alone: I'le have no Cuckold sup in my House to Night.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: 'Tis a very hot Evening, your Worship will sup in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Why, yes marry, I will Sir; what of that?

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: Why, your Worship was ever as good as your word, keep the Cuckolds out of doors, and lay a Cloth for my Lord in the Arbour. [Exit

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: I have been about a Project these three months, Fido.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: What is't, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: To compose a Book of my Wives Vertues; a Pattern for all that marry.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: That will do well, Sir: I have another too for you; but that we'll discourse as we go.
sp.l: Conceit and Confidence are Juglers born;
One grafts in Air, t'other hides the real Horn. [Exit.

div.head: ACT III.
div.stage: Enter Sir Cornelius like a Fryer, Fido.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: AM I fitted Fido, am I fitted?

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: To the life, Sir; and able to cheat suspition: and so like Father Anthony the Confessor, that I protest there's not more semblance in a pair of Eggs; an Apple cut in half, is not so like.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Well, you have counsell'd me to this, and I in this habit shall know the Core of her Heart.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: By this time she may be comming; I'le step aside: You'le tell what's done.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: What, reveal confession? But go your ways; as much as may lawfully be revealed we'le laugh at next meeting.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: Well, much good may you find:
sp.l: I have rais'd the storm, let who can lay the wind. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Yonder she comes, I can hardly forbear blushing; but I must have a care of discovery.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Hail Father.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Welcome my chast Daughter.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Death having taken my Father Joseph, to you I fall for absolution.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Empty then my Daughter that Vessel of thy Flesh of all the Dregs.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Since last I confest my first Sin was, That my Taylor, not making my Now Gown to my mind, in an unchristian Passon I bid the Devil take him.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: That was something harsh, yet the more pardonable, because, may be, your Taylor lies in Hell night by night: Pray to your second.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Next, in a most savage rage, my Chambermaid putting too much Blew in her Starch, I most unmercifully broke her Head.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: That was rashly done indeed Daughter: but are you sure the Maids Head was not broke before?

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: No, no: she came to me with ne're a crack about her.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: These are trivial and light: Have you greater?

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Yes Sir, one.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: One: what should that be, I wonder!

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: One yet remains behind of weight and consequence.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: She has trod some Chicken to death, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.l: Hear me, and let a blush make you look red;
Unseemly I've abus'd my Husbands Bed.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: You did ill to drink so hard that Night.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Alas, you are mistaken; I have lai'n with another Man besides my Husband.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Nay the same way I use to lye with him, but not altogether so often.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Death and the Devil: You're somewhat broad, but I have a Pennance for your Whoreship. Are you not with Child, Daughter?

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Yes, yes: sure 'twas that Nights work.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: How know you that?

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Alass, by experience, Sir: The kind Fool my Husband wishes all well; but like a light piece of Gold, he's taken for more than he weighs.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: With Child that charges too: there should follow a zealous Exhortation, but great Affairs brooks no stay: You are ingeniously sorrow.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Yes indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: And resolve to fall no more so?

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: No in truth, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Then I pronounce you here absolv'd. Now for your Pennance.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Anything.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: As the Fact seems strange, so blame me not if your Pennance be as strange, though 'tis easie perform'd: 'Tis neither East, Prayer, nor Pilgrimage.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Let it be what 'twill, I vow the performance.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Soon at Night, when you are with your Husband at Supper, or any other way in Publick, you shall say aloud to him, You are not this Childs Father, but such a Man is; naming the right Father as you think was Partner in your Sin.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Good Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: This is it I expect to have done you know the danger of breaking it; 'tis nothing.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Nothing: Is this your Pennance so wondrous easie in performance?

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: 'Tis irrevokable.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: I am silent: Your new Pennance may meet a new Performance: Farewel, Sir.
sp.l: You are the cruell'st e're confessed me before: [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: And this is a trick to catch a canting Whore. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: Come Phillis, be not so melancholly, the Sparks are in view.

sp.speaker: Sir Isa.
sp.p: Good morrow sweet Madam: Oh look how like the Sun behind a Cloud she beams to give intelligence how 'tis there.

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: You are reciprocally welcome, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Isa.
sp.p: What, have you brought this young wild Haggard to the Lure.

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: Faith Sir, she's a little irregular yet, but time may bring the wonder about.

sp.speaker: Sir Isa.
sp.p: Bless you, sweet Mistris.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.p: 'Uds foot, here's another Fleshmonger; I smell a Storm.

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p:
Sir, you are methodically welcome; you must pardon my variety
of phrase, the Courtiers e'ne clog us with good words.

sp.speaker: Sir Isa.
sp.p: What's he?

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: Why Sir, 'tis a German Prince, but a speaks English.

sp.speaker: Sir Isa.
sp.p: Did not I charge you to keep her for me? how dare you set her out to fail?

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: Indeed Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Isa.
sp.p: Indeed Sir; Pox of your indeeds Sir. [Kicks her.

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: Oh my Sciatica!

sp.speaker: Sir Isa.
sp.p: You Sir, she says, you'r a German Prince: I can't help it. [Kicks Fido; they draw.

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: Nay, good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.p: Good Sir, 'tis one of the Dukes Chamber.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: Let him be of the Devils Chamber.

sp.speaker: Sir Isa.
sp.p: Sirrah, leave the House, or I'le thunder you out.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.p: Sir, 'tis madness to stand him.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: Kickt; pray that we meet no more again Sir; still keep Heaven about you. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: VVhat e're thou art, a good man still go with thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Isa.
sp.p: VVill you bestow a Cast of your Profession?

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: VVe are vanish'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Oh! what shall become of me? in his eye murder and lust contends.

sp.speaker: Sir Isa.
sp.p: Nay, fly not sweet, I am not angry with you; do you know me?

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Yes Sir, report has given you to be the Lord Generous, but I fear Fame's a lyar.

sp.speaker: Sir Isa.
sp.p: Why so, Madam?

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Were you that Lord, you will not sure be a slave to your Bloods passion, to haunt such houses as these: I crave your pardon for my language, Truth has a Forehead free, and in the Tower of her Integrity fits an unvanquish'd Virgin.

sp.speaker: Sir Isa.
sp.p: If you rail upon the place; prethee, how came you hither?

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: By treacherous intelligence, honest men so Ignorant of the way, through Thieves perils go. This is a Cave of Scorpions and Dragons: Oh turn back!
sp.l: Toads here ingender, 'tis the Steam of Death,
The very Air poysons a good mans breath.

sp.speaker: Sir Isa.
sp.p: Within there.

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: Sir, did you call? I hope you found her plyant: Your Coach waits you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Isa.
sp.p: You are a rotten Hospital hung with greasie Sattin. [Kicks her.

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: Ah! ah me!

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.p: Came this nice piece from France, with a Pox to her?

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: If she has not warm'd his Stomach, I'le be stead for't. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Isa.
sp.p: I have more to say, will you meet me at Sir Cornelius Credulous house? my intents are virtuous, there I'le discover.
sp.l: Let me borrow goodness from thy lip, farewell:
Here's a new wonder, I have met Heaven in Hell. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: I know that voice, I dare not think of ill, and I will meet at Sir Cornelius's house: No, Sir Isaac,
sp.l: Had Law to this new Love made no denial,
A Chaste Wifes truth shines through the greatest tryal. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Let it be carried with a silent Reputation, for the credit of the Conclusion: I do not desire to be laught at, till my designs are ripe, and she has perform'd her Penance.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: Is this your Chaste Religious Wife? you see now 'tis possible for a cunning Wife to make an Ass of her Husband.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: An Ass; I will prove a contented Cuckold the wisest man in his company.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: How? Prove you that, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Because he knows himself. Mocko, Are all things ready to entertain our Guess?

sp.speaker: Mocko.
sp.p: Yes Sir, and by the way I met the Knight Sir Jealousie, and he and a strange Lady do intend to invite themselves to Supper to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: A shall be welcome, he will be fit company.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: No, I fear he wrongs his Wife with idle suspition; I dare, and will avow it with my life, Muchcraft keeps before Sir.
VVhy don't you, Mocko, keep all well behind?

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p:
I, and then there will be devout Lechery, between Hawk
and Buzzard: Mocko, draw out the Table with the Banquet.
sp.stage: [A Table furnish'd with all sorts of Horns in Dishes.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Now fie upon this variety, 'tis profane; Chastity defend me srom such a Meeting.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: Why Madam, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: There was a Lady invited to such a Treat, and going home in the dark, though as Chaste as Night, yet the poor Fellow, her Husband, lost her in a throng, and the good Soul came home so crush'd in the morning.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Sir Isaac, welcom.

sp.speaker: Sir Isa.
sp.p: Fido, I am throughly sensible of my Ladies Loyalty, and thy true Honourable Friendship; I beg your pardon for what has past in my folly and rage, and now could wish my Lady was here, that I might reconcile my self to her, and obtain her forgiveness for my wronging the Innocent.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Have a care what you say, Sir Isaac: Pray sit; come, all sit.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: I'le give you a fair occasion to produce the performance of her Penance.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Go forward, I'le catch occasion by the Forelock.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: Here's a Health to you, it shall go round.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: 'Tis a general Health, and leads the rest into the Field.

sp.speaker: Mocko.
sp.p: Your Worship breaks Jests, as Serving-men do Glasses, by chance.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: As I was drinking, I was thinking, trust me, how fortunate our kind Host was to meet with so Chast a Wife: Good Sir Cornelius, admit Heaven had her.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Oh, good Sir, do not wound me! Admit Heaven had her! 'Las Sir, what shou'd Heaven do with her?

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: Your love makes you passionate; but admit so, what Wife would you chuse?

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Were I to chuse then, as I would I were; so this were in Barbados, I would wish Sir, a Wife so like my Lady, that once a Week she should go to Confession, and to perform the Penance she should run; nay, do naught but dream on't till it was done.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: There's a delicate Momento, to put her in mind of her Penance.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Now you talk of Dreams, Sweet-heart, I'le tell you a very unhappy one; I was a-dream 't last night of Muchcraft.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Of Muchcraft.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Nay, I have done with him.

sp.speaker: Mocko.
sp.p: Now you shall see the Devil out-done.

sp.speaker: Sir Isa.
sp.p: Pray on with your Dream, 'twill be good diversion.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Bless me, I am e'ne ashamed Chick; but 'tis no matter, a Dream's a Dream, and thus it was; methought, Husband, Muchcraft lay with me.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: The best friend at home still, Muchcraft; Could the Devil, Sir, perform a Penance neater, and save his Credit better? On Wife, a Dream's a Dream I know.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Methought I prov'd with Child, Sweetheart.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Ay, Bird.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: A pox of these Dreams.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Methought I was brought to bed; and one day sitting in the Gallery, who should come there to play at Foyls, but thee and Muchcraft.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Muchcraft and I; do you mark that?

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: Ay; and wonder at her neat conveyance on't.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Playing, methought he hit you a blow on the Forehead; it swell'd so, thou could'st not see: at which the child cried.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: Excellent Woman at a shift: but I'le have a trick for her. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: And my thought at last you came thinking to quiet it, and it cried the more; whereat pointing to you, away naughty Man, you are not this Childs Father.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Meaning the Child Muchcraft got?

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: The same: And then I wak'd and kist you.

sp.speaker: Sir Isa.
sp.p: A pretty Dream, and a merry one.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: Sir, I am told there's one Father Anthony, a holy man, stays without to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: With me, or my Lady.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: Nay, with you, and a business of importance.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: I'le go send him in, and he shall interpret my Ladies dream. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Husband, Sir Cornelius, stay a little.

sp.speaker: Mocko.
sp.p: I smell Wormwood and Vinegar.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: She changes colour, I must out again. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: He will not sure reveal Confession.

sp.speaker: Sir Isa.
sp.p: We many times make modest mirth a necessity to produce a Ladies dream.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Would I were in France; how they shoot at us?

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: I am a bold intruder to this house, and am come in Quest of one my Lord Generous.

sp.speaker: Sir Isa.
sp.p: He will be here instantly: 'tis she, I can hardly forbear discovery; but I will bridle till Sir Cornelius returns.

div.stage: Enter Fido, Sir Cornelius like a Fryar.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: Here's brave jugling; this Fryar has confest, that you Lady in your last Confession owned, that Muchcraft had lain with you; at which your Husband runs mad about the Garden.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Art mad? deny it, I am undone else.

sp.speaker: Mocko.
sp.p: Father Tony, what a Devil do you mean to do?

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: I confess it, I deny it; I do any thing, I do every thing, I do nothing.

sp.speaker: Sir Isa.
sp.p: The Fryars frantick, and so has wrong'd the Lady.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: 'Tis my misfortune still to suffer Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: Did you not see one slip out of a Cloak-bag, in the fashion of a Gammon of Bacon, and run under the Table among the Hogs?

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: He's mad, he's mad.

sp.speaker: Mocko.
sp.p: I, I, a Tyth-Pig was overlaid last night, and he spoke nonsense all the day after.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Shall I suffer this in my own house?

sp.speaker: Mocko.
sp.p: I'd scratch out his eyes first.

sp.speaker: Sir Isa.
sp.p: Faith Madam, the best way is to disrobe this irregular Fryar, and lay him open to all the world: Tear off his holy Weeds.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Now my frantick Brother, had you not better spar'd your breath?

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: And do you keep counsel no better? we'll ease you of your Orders.

sp.speaker: Mocko.
sp.p: Nay, let me have a hand in't; I'le tear with more zeal than a Puritan would a Surplice.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: See what it is to accuse when you'r mad; I confess again to you, this man did lye with me.

sp.speaker: Mocko.
sp.p: And I brought him to her Chamber.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: A ha house! this Sir Cornelius!

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: How Dreams do fall out true, Wife?

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.p: Oh, good Sir, I crave you pardon.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: What say you, Muchcraft?

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.l: You have run best Sir, vain 'tis to defend,
Craft sets forth swift, but still fails in the end.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: You brought him to her Chamber, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: Oh Sir, I was meerly inveagl'd.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Lust is still like a midnight Meal, after our violent drinkings:
sp.l: 'Tis swallow'd greedily, but the Course being kept,
We are sicker when we wake, than e're we slept.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: You shall to Flanders to a Monastery, and spend your days reclusive.

sp.speaker: Polic.
sp.l: Your Doom is just; no Sentence can be given
Too hard for her, plays fast and loose with Heaven.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: I will buss thee, and bid fair weather after thec. But for you, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: Sir, I brought but flest to flesh, and you do as much when you bring your Meat to your Mouth.

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: You Sirrah, at a Carts Tail shall be whipe thorow the City: I am a Justice of Peace, and will see it done.

sp.speaker: Mock.
sp.p: There's my dream out already; but since there's no remedy but the Whipping chear must close up my stomach: I will request a Note from your Hand to the Carman, to intreat him to drive apace, I shall never endure it else.

sp.speaker: Sir Isa.
sp.p: 'Twas a sine Penance; but Oh the Art of Woman in the performance!

sp.speaker: Sir Cor.
sp.p: 'Tis nothing, had she bin in her great Grannums place:
sp.l: Had not the Devil first began the Sin,
And cheated her, she would have cheated him.

sp.speaker: Sir Isa.
sp.p: Now if my Innocentia was but here to clear my grief, then all our Joys were compleat.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Then here she stands spotless and innocent Heaven can testifie, and all good men cann't deny.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: I'le add my Life and Sword to justifie she's a matchless piece of virtue, and so receive her.

sp.speaker: Sir Isa.
sp.p: I am easily perswaded to't, for I have made a tryal on't my self, and found her all Excellence: Oh pardon me.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: I do; and pray Heaven may: And now,
Receive me just, both in my Life and Vow.

sp.speaker: Sir Isa.
sp.l: Vice for a time may shine and Virtue sigh;
But truth like Heavens seen, plainly doest reveal,
And scourge or crown, what darkness did conceal. [Exit.

div.head: The PROLOGUE.

l.hi: JUst so a Crack, first vent'ring on the Sin,
Does with reluctancy and fear begin.
As we Gallants (when such as you are here)

div.l: Produce our homely Cate's plain countrey Chear.

l.hi: But yet we scorn to do like some that write
Make use of Art, to raise your Appetite:
And make you think they have prepar'd a Feast,
When 'tis but Husks and Element at best.
No; we acknowledge we have nothing here
Worthy your least acceptance can appear.
Yet such as our poor Fate hath kept in store,
We freely give, and wish we could give more.

div.l: And as the Persian Monarch when distrest,

l.hi: Swore filthy Puddle-Water was the best
Pleasantest Drink he ever tasted: So,
Since ripe Town-Wit does not ith' Countrey grow:
We humbly hope for once these Green Fruits may,
If not suffice, your Appetite allay;
And be accepted of.
But if our Fate you otherwise decree,
We must submit without reluctancy.
And in our Ruin we shall still rejoyce,
That such as You, 'twas, gave the Casting Voice.

div.head: The EPILOGUE.

l.hi: WEll, Gentlemen, you've heard my Dreadful Doom,

div.l: In a dull Nunnery I must now consume

l.hi: My Blooming Youth; and watch, and fast, and pray,
To take the Guilt of my past sins away.
But faith, Gallants, I'le e'ne appeal to you,
'Tis damnably unjust, and cruel too:
Because I once oblig'd a Friend, or so;
Must I to Eternal Penance therefore go?
Must I, because I have to some been kind,
For ever be secluded from Mankind,
And those sweet dear delights we reap in Love,

div.l: And pine my self away?—Not I by Jove.

l.hi: Thanks to my Stars, our Sex as yet is free,

div.l: Kind England grants us Christian Liberty;

l.hi: And some of you, no doubt, would be so good,
To pity and relieve poor Flesh and Blood:
Nay, 'tis but a just Tribute due to Beauty,
For you did first debauch us from our duty;
You subtilly teach us first to go astray,
And, would ye, would ye, cast us then away?
No Faith, I'm sure ye dare not ▪
For if you once begin to sham us so,
'I'would make us Wives, e'ne down-right honest grow;
And then, alas, what would become of you?
You'd find but little amorous work to do:
Then 'faith reverse my Sentence; if you don't,
When e're you'd do the Feat, be sure we wont.
